chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:1
verses.text: Chapter - 1—On Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:2
verses.text: Of the Gnostic so much has been cursorily, as it were, written.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:3
verses.text: We proceed now to the sequel, and must again contemplate faith; for there are some that draw the distinction, that faith has reference to the Son, and knowledge to the Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:4
verses.text: But it has escaped their notice that, in order to believe truly in the Son, we must believe that He is the Son, and that He came, and how, and for what, and respecting His passion; and we must know who is the Son of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:5
verses.text: Now neither is knowledge without faith, nor faith without knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:6
verses.text: Nor is the Father without the Son; for the Son is with the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:7
verses.text: And the Son is the true teacher respecting the Father; and that we may believe in the Son, we must know the Father, with whom also is the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:8
verses.text: Again, in order that we may know the Father, we must believe in the Son, that it is the Son of God who teaches; for from faith to knowledge by the Son is the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:9
verses.text: And the knowledge of the Son and Father, which is according to the gnostic rule—that which in reality is gnostic—is the attainment and comprehension of the truth by the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:10
verses.text: We, then, are those who are believers in what is not believed, and who are Gnostics as to what is unknown; that is, Gnostics as to what is unknown and disbelieved by all, but believed and known by a few; and Gnostics, not describing actions by speech, but Gnostics in the exercise of contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:11
verses.text: Happy is he who speaks in the ears of the hearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:12
verses.text: Now faith is the ear of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:13
verses.text: And such the Lord intimates faith to be, when He says, "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear;" so that by believing he may comprehend what He says, as He says it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:14
verses.text: Homer, too, the oldest of the poets, using the word "hear" instead of "perceive"—the specific for the generic term—writes:—  "Him most they heard".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:15
verses.text: For, in fine, the agreement and harmony of the faith of both contribute to one end—salvation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:16
verses.text: We have in the apostle an unerring witness: "For I desire to see you, that I may impart unto you some spiritual gift, in order that ye may be strengthened; that is, that I may be comforted in you, by the mutual faith of you and me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:17
verses.text: And further on again he adds, "The righteousness of God is revealed from faith to faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:18
verses.text: The apostle, then, manifestly announces a twofold faith, or rather one which admits of growth and perfection; for the common faith lies beneath as a foundation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:19
verses.text: To those, therefore, who desire to be healed, and are moved by faith, He added, "Thy faith hath saved thee".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:20
verses.text: But that which is excellently built upon is consummated in the believer, and is again perfected by the faith which results from instruction and the word, in order to the performance of the commandments.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:21
verses.text: Such were the apostles, in whose case it is said that "faith removed mountains and transplanted trees".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:22
verses.text: Whence, perceiving the greatness of its power, they asked "that faith might be added to them;" a faith which salutarily bites the soil "like a grain of mustard," and grows magnificently in it, to such a degree that the reasons of things sublime rest on it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:23
verses.text: For if one by nature knows God, as Basilides thinks, who calls intelligence of a superior order at once faith and kingship, and a creation worthy of the essence of the Creator; and explains that near Him exists not power, but essence and nature and substance; and says that faith is not the rational assent of the soul exercising free-will, but an undefined beauty, belonging immediately to the creature;—the precepts both of the Old and of the New Testament are, then, superfluous, if one is saved by  nature, as Valentinus would have it, and is a believer and an elect man by nature, as Basilides thinks; and nature would have been able, one time or other, to have shone forth, apart from the Saviour's appearance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:24
verses.text: But were they to say that the visit of the Saviour was necessary, then the properties of nature are gone from them, the elect being saved by instruction, and purification, and the doing of good works.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:25
verses.text: Abraham, accordingly, who through hearing believed the voice, which promised under the oak in Mamre, "I will give this land to thee, and to thy seed," was either elect or not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:26
verses.text: But if he was not, how did he straightway believe, as it were naturally? And if he was elect, their hypothesis is done away with, inasmuch as even previous to the coming of the Lord an election was found, and that saved: "For it was reckoned to him for righteousness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:27
verses.text: For if any one, following Marcion, should dare to say that the Creator (Δημιουργόν) saved the man that believed on him, even before the advent of the Lord, (the election being saved with their own proper salvation); the power of the good Being will be eclipsed; inasmuch as late only, and subsequent to the Creator spoken of by them in words of good omen, it made the attempt to save, and by instruction, and in imitation of him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:28
verses.text: But if, being such, the good Being save, according to them; neither is it his own that he saves, nor is it with the consent of him who formed the creation that he essays salvation, but by force or fraud.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:29
verses.text: And how can he any more be good, acting thus, and being posterior? But if the locality is different, and the dwelling-place of the Omnipotent is remote from the dwelling-place of the good God; yet the will of him who saves, having been the first to begin, is not inferior to that of the good God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:30
verses.text: From what has been previously proved, those who believe not are proved senseless: "For their paths are perverted, and they know not peace," saith the prophet.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:31
verses.text: "But foolish and unlearned questions" the divine Paul exhorted to "avoid, because they gender strifes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:32
verses.text: And aeschylus exclaims:—  "In what profits not, labour not in vain".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:33
verses.text: For that investigation, which accords with faith, which builds, on the foundation of faith, the august knowledge of the truth, we know to be the best.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:34
verses.text: Now we know that neither things which are clear are made subjects of investigation, such as if it is day, while it is day; nor things unknown, and never destined to become clear, as whether the stars are even or odd in number; nor things convertible; and those are so which can be said equally by those who take the opposite side, as if what is in the womb is a living creature or not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:35
verses.text: A fourth mode is, when, from either side of those, there is advanced an unanswerable and irrefragable argument.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:36
verses.text: If, then, the ground of inquiry, according to all of these modes, is removed, faith is established.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:37
verses.text: For we advance to them the unanswerable consideration, that it is God who speaks and comes to our help in writing, respecting each one of the points regarding which I investigate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:38
verses.text: Who, then, is so impious as to disbelieve God, and to demand proofs from God as from men? Again, some questions demand the evidence of the senses, as if one were to ask whether the fire be warm, or the snow white; and some admonition and rebuke, as the question if you ought to honour your parents.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:39
verses.text: And there are those that deserve punishment, as to ask proofs of the existence of Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:40
verses.text: There being then a Providence, it were impious to think that the whole of prophecy and the economy in reference to a Saviour did not take place in accordance with Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:41
verses.text: And perchance one should not even attempt to demonstrate such points, the divine Providence being evident from the sight of all its skilful and wise works which are seen, some of which take place in order, and some appear in order.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:42
verses.text: And He who communicated to us being and life, has communicated to us also reason, wishing us to live rationally and rightly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:43
verses.text: For the Word of the Father of the universe is not the uttered word (λόγος προφορικός), but the wisdom and most manifest kindness of God, and His power too, which is almighty and truly divine, and not incapable of being conceived by those who do not confess—the all-potent will.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:44
verses.text: But since some are unbelieving, and some are disputatious, all do not attain to the perfection of the good.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:45
verses.text: For neither is it possible to attain it without the exercise of free choice; nor does the whole depend on our own purpose; as, for example, what is defined to happen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:46
verses.text: "For by grace we are saved:" not, indeed, without good works; but we must, by being formed for what is good, acquire an inclination for it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:47
verses.text: And we must possess the healthy mind which is fixed on the pursuit of the good; in order to which we have the greatest need of divine grace, and of right teaching, and of holy susceptibility, and of the drawing of the Father to Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:48
verses.text: For, bound in this earthly body, we apprehend the objects of sense by means of the body; but we grasp intellectual objects by means of the logical faculty itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:49
verses.text: But if one expect to apprehend all things by the senses, he has fallen far from the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:50
verses.text: Spiritually, therefore, the apostle writes respecting the knowledge of God,  "For now we see as through a glass, but then face to face".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:51
verses.text: For the vision of the truth is given but to few.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:52
verses.text: Accordingly, Plato says in the Epinomis, "I do not say that it is possible for all to be blessed and happy; only a few.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:53
verses.text: Whilst we live, I pronounce this to be the case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:54
verses.text: But there is a good hope that after death I shall attain all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:55
verses.text: To the same effect is what we find in Moses: "No man shall see My face, and live".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:56
verses.text: For it is evident that no one during the period of life has been able to apprehend God clearly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:57
verses.text: But "the pure in heart shall see God," when they arrive at the final perfection.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:58
verses.text: For since the soul became too enfeebled for the apprehension of realities, we needed a divine teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:59
verses.text: The Saviour is sent down—a teacher and leader in the acquisition of the good—the secret and sacred token of the great Providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:60
verses.text: "Where, then, is the scribe? where is the searcher of this world? Hath not God made foolish the wisdom of this world?" it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:61
verses.text: And again, "I will destroy the wisdom of the wise, and bring to nothing the understanding of the prudent," plainly of those wise in their own eyes, and disputatious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:62
verses.text: Excellently therefore Jeremiah says, "Thus saith the Lord, Stand in the ways, and ask for the eternal paths, what is the good way, and walk in it, and ye shall find expiation for your souls".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:63
verses.text: Ask, he says, and inquire of those who know, without contention and dispute.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:64
verses.text: And on learning the way of truth, let us walk on the right way, without turning till we attain to what we desire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:65
verses.text: It was therefore with reason that the king of the Romans (his name was Numa), being a Pythagorean, first of all men, erected a temple to Faith and Peace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:66
verses.text: "And to Abraham, on believing, righteousness was reckoned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:67
verses.text: He, prosecuting the lofty philosophy of aerial phenomena, and the sublime philosophy of the movements in the heavens, was called Abram, which is interpreted "sublime father".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:68
verses.text: But afterwards, on looking up to heaven, whether it was that he saw the Son in the spirit, as some explain, or a glorious angel, or in any other way recognised God to be superior to the creation, and all the order in it, he receives in addition the Alpha, the knowledge of the one and only God, and is called Abraam, having, instead of a natural philosopher, become wise, and a lover of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:69
verses.text: For it is interpreted, "elect father of sound".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:70
verses.text: For by sound is the uttered word: the mind is its father; and the mind of the good man is elect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:71
verses.text: I cannot forbear praising exceedingly the poet of Agrigentum, who celebrates faith as follows:—  "Friends, I know, then, that there is truth in the myths Which I will relate.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:72
verses.text: But very difficult to men, And irksome to the mind, is the attempt of faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:73
verses.text: Wherefore also the apostle exhorts, "that your faith should not be in the wisdom of men," who profess to persuade, "but in the power of God," which alone without proofs, by mere faith, is able to save.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:74
verses.text: "For the most approved of those that are reputable knows how to keep watch.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:75
verses.text: And justice will apprehend the forgers and witnesses of lies," says the Ephesian.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:76
verses.text: For he, having derived his knowledge from the barbarian philosophy, is acquainted with the purification by fire of those who have led bad lives, which the Stoics afterwards called the Conflagration (ἐκπύρωσις), in which also they teach that each will arise exactly as he was, so treating of the resurrection; while Plato says as follows, that the earth at certain periods is purified by fire and water: "There have been many destructions of men in many ways; and there shall be very great ones by fire and water; and others briefer by innumerable causes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:77
verses.text: And after a little he adds: "And, in truth, there is a change of the objects which revolve about earth and heaven; and in the course of long periods there is the destruction of the objects on earth by a great conflagration".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:78
verses.text: Then he subjoins respecting the deluge: "But when, again, the gods deluge the earth to purify it with water, those on the mountains, herdsmen and shepherds, are saved; those in your cities are carried down by the rivers into the sea".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:79
verses.text: And we showed in the first Miscellany that the philosophers of the Greeks are called thieves, inasmuch as they have taken without acknowledgment their principal dogmas from Moses and the prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:80
verses.text: To which also we shall add, that the angels who had obtained the superior rank, having sunk into pleasures, told to the women the secrets which had come to their knowledge; while the rest of the angels concealed them, or rather, kept them against the coming of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:81
verses.text: Thence emanated the doctrine of providence, and the revelation of high things; and prophecy having already been imparted to the philosophers of the Greeks, the treatment of dogma arose among the philosophers, sometimes true when they hit the mark, and sometimes erroneous, when they comprehended not the secret of the prophetic allegory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:82
verses.text: And this it is proposed briefly to indicate in running over the points requiring mention.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:83
verses.text: Faith, then, we say, we are to show must not be  inert and alone, but accompanied with investigation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:84
verses.text: For I do not say that we are not to inquire at all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:85
verses.text: For "Search, and thou shalt find," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:86
verses.text: "What is sought may be captured, But what is neglected escapes,"  according to Sophocles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:87
verses.text: The like also says Menander the comic poet:—  "All things sought, The wisest say, need anxious thought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:88
verses.text: But we ought to direct the visual faculty of the soul aright to discovery, and to clear away obstacles; and to cast clean away contention, and envy, and strife, destined to perish miserably from among men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:89
verses.text: For very beautifully does Timon of Phlius write:—  "And Strife, the Plague of Mortals, stalks vainly shrieking, The sister of Murderous Quarrel and Discord, Which rolls blindly over all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:90
verses.text: But then It sets its head towards men, and casts them on hope".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:91
verses.text: Then a little below he adds:—  "For who hath set these to fight in deadly strife? A rabble keeping pace with Echo; for, enraged at those silent, It raised an evil disease against men, and many perished;"  of the speech which denies what is false, and of the dilemma, of that which is concealed, of the Sorites, and of the Crocodilean, of that which is open, and of ambiguities and sophisms.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:92
verses.text: To inquire, then, respecting God, if it tend not to strife, but to discovery, is salutary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:93
verses.text: For it is written in David, "The poor eat, and shall be filled; and they shall praise the Lord that seek Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:94
verses.text: Your heart shall live for ever".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:95
verses.text: For they who seek Him after the true search, praising the Lord, shall be filled with the gift that comes from God, that is, knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:96
verses.text: And their soul shall live; for the soul is figuratively termed the heart, which ministers life: for by the Son is the Father known.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:97
verses.text: We ought not to surrender our ears to all who speak and write rashly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:98
verses.text: For cups also, which are taken hold of by many by the ears, are dirtied, and lose the ears; and besides, when they fall they are broken.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:99
verses.text: In the same way also, those, who have polluted the pure hearing of faith by many trifles, at last becoming deaf to the truth, become useless and fall to the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:100
verses.text: It is not, then, without reason that we commanded boys to kiss their relations, holding them by the ears; indicating this, that the feeling of love is engendered by hearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:101
verses.text: And "God," who is known to those who love, "is love," as "God," who by instruction is communicated to the faithful, "is faithful;" and we must be allied to Him by divine love: so that by like we may see like, hearing the word of truth guilelessly and purely, as children who obey us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:102
verses.text: And this was what he, whoever he was, indicated who wrote on the entrance to the temple at Epidaurus the inscription:—  "Pure he must be who goes within The incense-perfumed fane".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:103
verses.text: And purity is "to think holy thoughts".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:104
verses.text: "Except ye become as these little children, ye shall not enter," it is said, "into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 2:105
verses.text: For there the temple of God is seen established on three foundations—faith, hope, and love.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:1
verses.text: Chapter - 2—On Hope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:2
verses.text: Respecting faith we have adduced sufficient testimonies of writings among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:3
verses.text: But in order not to exceed bounds, through eagerness to collect a very great many also respecting hope and love, suffice it merely to say that in the Crito Socrates, who prefers a good life and death to life itself, thinks that we have hope of another life after death.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:4
verses.text: Also in the Phoedrus he says, "That only when in a separate state can the soul become partaker of the wisdom which is true, and surpasses human power; and when, having reached the end of hope by philosophic love, desire shall waft it to heaven, then," says he, "does it receive the commencement of another, an immortal life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:5
verses.text: And in the Symposium he says, "That there is instilled into all the natural love of generating what is like, and in men of generating men alone, and in the good man of the generation of the counterpart of himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:6
verses.text: But it is impossible for the good man to do this without possessing the perfect virtues, in which he will train the youth who have recourse to him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:7
verses.text: And as he says in the Theoetetus,"He will beget and finish men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:8
verses.text: For some procreate by the body, others by the soul;" since also with the barbarian philosophers to teach and enlighten is called to regenerate; and "I have begotten you in Jesus Christ," says the good apostle somewhere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:9
verses.text: Empedocles, too, enumerates friendship among the elements, conceiving it as a combining love:—  "Which do you look at with your mind; and don't sit gaping with your eyes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 3:10
verses.text: Parmenides, too, in his poem, alluding to hope, speaks thus:—  "Yet look with the mind certainly on what is absent as present, For it will not sever that which is from the grasp it has of that which is Not, even if scattered in every direction over the world or combined".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 3—The Objects of Faith and Hope Perceived by the Mind Alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:2
verses.text: For he who hopes, as he who believes, sees intellectual objects and future things with the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:3
verses.text: If, then, we affirm that aught is just, and affirm it to be good, and we also say that truth is something, yet we have never seen any of such objects with our eyes, but with our mind alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:4
verses.text: Now the Word of God says, "I am the truth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:5
verses.text: The Word is then to be contemplated by the mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:6
verses.text: "Do you aver," it was said, "that there are any true philosophers?" "Yes," said I, "those who love to contemplate the truth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:7
verses.text: In the Phoedrus also, Plato, speaking of the truth, shows it as an idea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:8
verses.text: Now an idea is a conception of God; and this the barbarians have termed the Word of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:9
verses.text: The words are as follow: "For one must then dare to speak the truth, especially in speaking of the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:10
verses.text: For the essence of the soul, being colourless, formless, and intangible, is visible only to God, its guide".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:11
verses.text: Now the Word issuing forth was the cause of creation; then also he generated himself, "when the Word had become flesh," that He might be seen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:12
verses.text: The righteous man will seek the discovery that flows from love, to which if he hastes he prospers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:13
verses.text: For it is said, "To him that knocketh, it shall be opened: ask, and it shall be given to you".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:14
verses.text: "For the violent that storm the kingdom" are not so in disputatious speeches; but by continuance in a right life and unceasing prayers, are said "to take it by force," wiping away the blots left by their previous sins.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:15
verses.text: "You may obtain wickedness, even in great abundance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:16
verses.text: And him who toils God helps; For the gifts of the Muses, hard to win, Lie not before you, for any one to bear away".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:17
verses.text: The knowledge of ignorance is, then, the first lesson in walking according to the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:18
verses.text: An ignorant man has sought, and having sought, he finds the teacher; and finding has believed, and believing has hoped; and henceforward having loved, is assimilated to what was loved—endeavouring to be what he first loved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:19
verses.text: Such is the method Socrates shows Alcibiades, who thus questions: "Do you not think that I shall know about what is right otherwise?" "Yes, if you have found out".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:20
verses.text: "But you don't think I have found out?" "Certainly, if you have sought".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:21
verses.text: "Then you don't think that I have sought?" "Yes, if you think you do not know".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:22
verses.text: So with the lamps of the wise virgins, lighted at night in the great darkness of ignorance, which the Scripture signified by "night".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:23
verses.text: Wise souls, pure as virgins, understanding themselves to be situated amidst the ignorance of the world, kindle the light, and rouse the mind, and illumine the darkness, and dispel ignorance, and seek truth, and await the appearance of the Teacher.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:24
verses.text: "The mob, then," said I, "cannot become philosopher".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:25
verses.text: "Many rod-bearers there are, but few Bacchi," according to Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:26
verses.text: "For many are called, but few chosen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:27
verses.text: "Knowledge is not in all," says the apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:28
verses.text: "And pray that we may be delivered from unreasonable and wicked men: for all men have not faith".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:29
verses.text: And the Poetics of Cleanthes, the Stoic, writes to the following effect:—  "Look not to glory, wishing to be suddenly wise, And fear not the undiscerning and rash opinion of the many; For the multitude has not an intelligent, or wise, or right judgment, And it is in few men that you will find this".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:30
verses.text: And more sententiously the comic poet briefly says:—  "It is a shame to judge of what is right by much noise".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:31
verses.text: For they heard, I think, that excellent wisdom, which says to us, "Watch your opportunity in the midst of the foolish, and in the midst of the intelligent continue".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:32
verses.text: And again, "The wise will conceal sense".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:33
verses.text: For the many demand demonstration as a pledge of truth, not satisfied with the bare salvation by faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:34
verses.text: "But it is strongly incumbent to disbelieve the dominant wicked, And as is enjoined by the assurance of our muse, Know by dissecting the utterance within your breast".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:35
verses.text: "For this is habitual to the wicked," says Empedocles, "to wish to overbear what is true by disbelieving it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:36
verses.text: And that our tenets are probable and worthy of belief, the Greeks shall know, the point being more thoroughly investigated in what follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:37
verses.text: For we are taught what is like by what is like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:38
verses.text: For says Solomon, "Answer a fool according to his folly".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:39
verses.text: Wherefore also, to those that ask the wisdom that is with us, we are to hold out things suitable, that with the greatest possible ease they may, through their own ideas, be likely to arrive at faith in the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:40
verses.text: For "I  became all things to all men, that I might gain all men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:41
verses.text: Since also "the rain" of the divine grace is sent down "on the just and the unjust".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 4:42
verses.text: "Is He the God of the Jews only, and not also of the Gentiles? Yes, also of the Gentiles: if indeed He is one God," exclaims the noble apostle.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 4—Divine Things Wrapped Up in Figures Both in the Sacred and in Heathen Writers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:2
verses.text: But since they will believe neither in what is good justly nor in knowledge unto salvation, we ourselves reckoning what they claim as belonging to us, because all things are God's; and especially since what is good proceeded from us to the Greeks, let us handle those things as they are capable of hearing.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:3
verses.text: For intelligence or rectitude this great crowd estimates not by truth, but by what they are delighted with.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:4
verses.text: And they will be pleased not more with other things than with what is like themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:5
verses.text: For he who is still blind and dumb, not having understanding, or the undazzled and keen vision of the contemplative soul, which the Saviour confers, like the uninitiated at the mysteries, or the unmusical at dances, not being yet pure and worthy of the pure truth, but still discordant and disordered and material, must stand outside of the divine choir.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:6
verses.text: "For we compare spiritual things with spiritual".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:7
verses.text: Wherefore, in accordance with the method of concealment, the truly sacred Word, truly divine and most necessary for us, deposited in the shrine of truth, was by the Egyptians indicated by what were called among them adyta, and by the Hebrews by the veil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:8
verses.text: Only the consecrated—that is, those devoted to God, circumcised in the desire of the passions for the sake of love to that which is alone divine—were allowed access to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:9
verses.text: For Plato also thought it not lawful for "the impure to touch the pure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:10
verses.text: Thence the prophecies and oracles are spoken in enigmas, and the mysteries are not exhibited incontinently to all and sundry, but only after certain purifications and previous instructions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:11
verses.text: "For the Muse was not then Greedy of gain or mercenary; Nor were Terpsichore's sweet, Honey-toned, silvery soft-voiced Strains made merchandise of".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:12
verses.text: Now those instructed among the Egyptians learned first of all that style of the Egyptian letters which is called Epistolographic; and second, the Hieratic, which the sacred scribes practice; and finally, and last of all, the Hieroglyphic, of which one kind which is by the first elements is literal (Kyriologic), and the other Symbolic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:13
verses.text: Of the Symbolic, one kind speaks literally by imitation, and another writes as it were figuratively; and another is quite allegorical, using certain enigmas.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:14
verses.text: Wishing to express Sun in writing, they makea circle; and Moon, a figure like the Moon, like its proper shape.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:15
verses.text: But in using the figurative style, by transposing and transferring, by changing and by transforming in many ways as suits them, they draw characters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:16
verses.text: In relating the praises of the kings in theological myths, they write in anaglyphs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:17
verses.text: Let the following stand as a specimen of the third species—the Enigmatic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:18
verses.text: For the rest of the stars, on account of their oblique course, they have figured like the bodies of serpents; but the sun, like that of a beetle, because it makes a round figure of ox-dung, and rolls it before its face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:19
verses.text: And they say that this creature lives six months under ground, and the other division of the year above ground, and emits its seed into the ball, and brings forth; and that there is not a female beetle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:20
verses.text: All then, in a word, who have spoken of divine things, both Barbarians and Greeks, have veiled the first principles of things, and delivered the truth in enigmas, and symbols, and allegories, and metaphors, and such like tropes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:21
verses.text: Such also are the oracles among the Greeks.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:22
verses.text: And the Pythian Apollo is called Loxias.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:23
verses.text: Also the maxims of those among the Greeks called wise men, in a few sayings indicate the unfolding of matter of considerable importance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:24
verses.text: Such certainly is that maxim, "Spare Time:" either because life is short, and we ought not to expend this time in vain; or, on the other hand, it bids you spare your personal expenses; so that, though you live many years, necessaries may not fail you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:25
verses.text: Similarly also the maxim "Know thyself" shows many things; both that thou art mortal, and that thou wast born a human being; and also that, in comparison with the other excellences of life, thou art of no account, because thou sayest that thou art rich or renowned; or, on the other hand, that, being rich or renowned, you are not honoured on account of your advantages alone.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:26
verses.text: And it says, Know for what thou wert born, and whose image thou art; and what is thy essence, and what thy creation, and what thy relation to God, and the like.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:27
verses.text: And the Spirit says by Isaiah the prophet, "I will give thee treasures, hidden, dark".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:28
verses.text: Now wisdom, hard to hunt, is the treasures of God and unfailing riches.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:29
verses.text: But those, taught in theology by those prophets, the poets, philosophize much by way of a hidden sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:30
verses.text: I mean Orpheus, Linus, Musaeus, Homer, and  Hesiod, and those in this fashion wise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:31
verses.text: The persuasive style of poetry is for them a veil for the many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:32
verses.text: Dreams and signs are all more or less obscure to men, not from jealousy (for it were wrong to conceive of God as subject to passions), but in order that research, introducing to the understanding of enigmas, may haste to the discovery of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:33
verses.text: Thus Sophocles the tragic poet somewhere says:—  "And God I know to be such an one, Ever the revealer of enigmas to the wise, But to the perverse bad, although a teacher in few words,"—  putting bad instead of simple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:34
verses.text: Expressly then respecting all our Scripture, as if spoken in a parable, it is written in the Psalms, "Hear, O My people, My law: incline your ear to the words of My mouth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:35
verses.text: I will open My mouth in parables, I will utter My problems from the beginning".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:36
verses.text: Similarly speaks the noble apostle to the following effect: "Howbeit we speak wisdom among those that are perfect; yet not the wisdom of this world, nor of the princes of this world, that come to nought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:37
verses.text: But we speak the wisdom of God hidden in a mystery; which none of the princes of this world knew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:38
verses.text: For had they known it, they would not have crucified the Lord of glory".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:39
verses.text: The philosophers did not exert themselves in contemning the appearance of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:40
verses.text: It therefore follows that it is the opinion of the wise among the Jews which the apostle inveighs against.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:41
verses.text: Wherefore he adds, "But we preach, as it is written, what eye hath not seen, and ear hath not heard, and hath not entered into the heart of man, what God hath prepared for them that love Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:42
verses.text: For God hath revealed it to us by the Spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:43
verses.text: For the Spirit searcheth all things, even the deep things of God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:44
verses.text: For he recognises the spiritual man and the Gnostic as the disciple of the Holy Spirit dispensed by God, which is the mind of Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:45
verses.text: "But the natural man receiveth not the things of the Spirit, for they are foolishness to him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:46
verses.text: Now the apostle, in contradistinction to gnostic perfection, calls the common faith the foundation, and sometimes milk, writing on this wise: "Brethren, I could not speak to you as to spiritual, but as to carnal, to babes in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:47
verses.text: I have fed you with milk, not with meat: for ye were not able.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:48
verses.text: Neither yet are ye now able.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:49
verses.text: For ye are yet carnal: for whereas there is among you envy and strife, are ye not carnal, and walk as men?" Which things are the choice of those men who are sinners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:50
verses.text: But those who abstain from these things give their thoughts to divine things, and partake of gnostic food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:51
verses.text: "According to the grace," it is said, "given to me as a wise master builder, I have laid the foundation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:52
verses.text: And another buildeth on it gold and silver, precious stones".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:53
verses.text: Such is the gnostic superstructure on the foundation of faith in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:54
verses.text: But "the stubble, and the wood, and the hay," are the additions of heresies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:55
verses.text: "But the fire shall try every man's work, of what sort it is".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:56
verses.text: In allusion to the gnostic edifice also in the Epistle to the Romans, he says, "For I desire to see you, that I may impart unto you a spiritual gift, that ye may be established".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 5:57
verses.text: It was impossible that gifts of this sort could be written without disguise.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 5—On the Symbols of Pythagoras.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:2
verses.text: Now the Pythagorean symbols were connected with the Barbarian philosophy in the most recondite way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:3
verses.text: For instance, the Samian counsels "not to have a swallow in the house;" that is, not to receive a loquacious, whispering, garrulous man, who cannot contain what has been communicated to him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:4
verses.text: "For the swallow, and the turtle, and the sparrows of the field, know the times of their entrance," says the Scripture; and one ought never to dwell with trifles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:5
verses.text: And the turtle-dove murmuring shows the thankless slander of fault-finding, and is rightly expelled the house.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:6
verses.text: "Don't mutter against me, sitting by one in one place, another in another".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:7
verses.text: The swallow too, which suggests the fable of Pandion, seeing it is right to detest the incidents reported of it, some of which we hear Tereus suffered, and some of which he inflicted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:8
verses.text: It pursues also the musical grasshoppers, whence he who is a persecutor of the word ought to be driven away.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:9
verses.text: "By sceptre-bearing Here, whose eye surveys Olympus, I have a rusty closet for tongues,"  says Poetry.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:10
verses.text: aeschylus also says:—  "But, I, too, have a key as a guard on my tongue".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:11
verses.text: Again Pythagoras commanded, "When the pot is lifted off the fire, not to leave its mark in the ashes, but to scatter them;" and "people on getting up from bed, to shake the bed-clothes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:12
verses.text: For he intimated that it was necessary not only to efface the mark, but not to leave even a trace of anger; and that on its ceasing to boil, it was to be composed, and all memory of injury to be wiped out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:13
verses.text: "And let not the sun," says the Scripture, "go down upon your wrath".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:14
verses.text: And he that said, "Thou shall not desire," took away all memory of wrong; for wrath is found  to be the impulse of concupiscence in a mild soul, especially seeking irrational revenge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:15
verses.text: In the same way "the bed is ordered to be shaken up," so that there may be no recollection of effusion in sleep, or sleep in the day-time; nor, besides, of pleasure during the night.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:16
verses.text: And he intimated that the vision of the dark ought to be dissipated speedily by the light of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:17
verses.text: "Be angry, and sin not," says David, teaching us that we ought not to assent to the impression, and not to follow it up by action, and so confirm wrath.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:18
verses.text: Again, "Don't sail on land" is a Pythagorean saw, and shows that taxes and similar contracts, being troublesome and fluctuating, ought to be declined.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:19
verses.text: Wherefore also the Word says that the tax-gatherers shall be saved with difficulty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:20
verses.text: And again, "Don't wear a ring, nor engrave on it the images of the gods," enjoins Pythagoras; as Moses ages before enacted expressly, that neither a graven, nor molten, nor moulded, nor painted likeness should be made; so that we may not cleave to things of sense, but pass to intellectual objects: for familiarity with the sight disparages the reverence of what is divine; and to worship that which is immaterial by matter, is to dishonour it by sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:21
verses.text: Wherefore the wisest of the Egyptian priests decided that the temple of Athene should be hypaethral, just as the Hebrews constructed the temple without an image.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:22
verses.text: And some, in worshipping God, make a representation of heaven containing the stars; and so worship, although Scripture says, "Let Us make man in Our image and likeness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:23
verses.text: I think it worth while also to adduce the utterance of Eurysus the Pythagorean, which is as follows, who in his book On Fortune, having said that the "Creator, on making man, took Himself as an exemplar," added, "And the body is like the other things, as being made of the same material, and fashioned by the best workman, who wrought it, taking Himself as the archetype".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:24
verses.text: And, in fine, Pythagoras and his followers, with Plato also, and most of the other philosophers, were best acquainted with the Lawgiver, as may be concluded from their doctrine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:25
verses.text: And by a happy utterance of divination, not without divine help, concurring in certain prophetic declarations, and, seizing the truth in portions and aspects, in terms not obscure, and not going beyond the explanation of the things, they honoured it on as certaining the appearance of relation with the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:26
verses.text: Whence the Hellenic philosophy is like the torch of wick which men kindle, artificially stealing the light from the sun.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:27
verses.text: But on the proclamation of the Word all that holy light shone forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:28
verses.text: Then in houses by night the stolen light is useful; but by day the fire blazes, and all the night is illuminated by such a sun of intellectual light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:29
verses.text: Now Pythagoras made an epitome of the statements on righteousness in Moses, when he said, "Do not step over the balance;" that is, do not transgress equality in distribution, honouring justice so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:30
verses.text: "Which friends to friends for ever, binds, To cities, cities—to allies, allies, For equality is what is right for men; But less to greater ever hostile grows, And days of hate begin,"  as is said with poetic grace.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:31
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord says, "Take My yoke, for it is gentle and light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:32
verses.text: And on the disciples, striving for the pre-eminence, He enjoins equality with simplicity, saying "that they must become as little children".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:33
verses.text: Likewise also the apostle writes, that "no one in Christ is bond or free, or Greek or Jew.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:34
verses.text: For the creation in Christ Jesus is new, is equality, free of strife—not grasping—just".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:35
verses.text: For envy, and jealousy, and bitterness, stand without the divine choir.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:36
verses.text: Thus also those skilled in the mysteries forbid "to eat the heart;" teaching that we ought not to gnaw and consume the soul by idleness and by vexation, on account of things which happen against one's wishes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:37
verses.text: Wretched, accordingly, was the man whom Homer also says, wandering alone, "ate his own heart".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:38
verses.text: But again, seeing the Gospel supposes two ways—the apostles, too, similarly with all the prophets—and seeing they call that one "narrow and confined" which is circumscribed according to the commandments and prohibitions, and the opposite one, which leads to perdition, "broad and roomy," open to pleasures and wrath, and say, "Blessed is the man who walketh not in the counsel of the ungodly, and standeth not in the way of sinners".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:39
verses.text: Hence also comes the fable of Prodicus of Ceus about Virtue and Vice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:40
verses.text: And Pythagoras shrinks not from prohibiting to walk on the public thoroughfares, enjoining the necessity of not following the sentiments of the many, which are crude and inconsistent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:41
verses.text: And Aristocritus, in the first book of his Positions against Heracliodorus, mentions a letter to this effect: "Atoeeas king of the Scythians to the people of Byzantium: Do not impair my revenues in case my mares drink your water;" for the Barbarian indicated symbolically that he would make war on them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:42
verses.text: Likewise also the poet Euphorion introduces Nestor saying,—  "We have not yet wet the Achaean steeds in Simois".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 6:43
verses.text: Therefore also the Egyptians place Sphinxes before their temples, to signify that the doctrine respecting God is enigmatical and obscure; perhaps also that we ought both to love and fear the Divine Being: to love Him as gentle and benign to the pious; to fear Him as inexorably just to the impious; for the sphinx shows the image of a wild beast and of a man together.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 6—The Mystic Meaning of the Tabernacle and Its Furniture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:2
verses.text: It were tedious to go over all the Prophets and the Law, specifying what is spoken in enigmas; for almost the whole Scripture gives its utterances in this way.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:3
verses.text: It may suffice, I think, for any one possessed of intelligence, for the proof of the point in hand, to select a few examples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:4
verses.text: Now concealment is evinced in the reference of the seven circuits around the temple, which are made mention of among the Hebrews; and the equipment on the robe, indicating by the various symbols, which had reference to visible objects, the agreement which from heaven reaches down to earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:5
verses.text: And the covering and the veil were variegated with blue, and purple, and scarlet, and linen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:6
verses.text: And so it was suggested that the nature of the elements contained the revelation of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:7
verses.text: For purple is from water, linen from the earth; blue, being dark, is like the air, as scarlet is like fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:8
verses.text: In the midst of the covering and veil, where the priests were allowed to enter, was situated the altar of incense, the symbol of the earth placed in the middle of this universe; and from it came the fumes of incense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:9
verses.text: And that place intermediate between the inner veil, where the high priest alone, on prescribed days, was permitted to enter, and the external court which surrounded it—free to all the Hebrews—was, they say, the middlemost point of heaven and earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:10
verses.text: But others say it was the symbol of the intellectual world, and that of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:11
verses.text: The covering, then, the barrier of popular unbelief, was stretched in front of the five pillars, keeping back those in the surrounding space.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:12
verses.text: So very mystically the five loaves are broken by the Saviour, and fill the crowd of the listeners.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:13
verses.text: For great is the crowd that keep to the things of sense, as if they were the only things in existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:14
verses.text: "Cast your eyes round, and see," says Plato, "that none of the uninitiated listen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:15
verses.text: Such are they who think that nothing else exists, but what they can hold tight with their hands; but do not admit as in the department of existence, actions and processes of generation, and the whole of the unseen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:16
verses.text: For such are those who keep by the five senses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:17
verses.text: But the knowledge of God is a thing inaccessible to the ears and like organs of this kind of people.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:18
verses.text: Hence the Son is said to be the Father's face, being the revealer of the Father's character to the five senses by clothing Himself with flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:19
verses.text: "But if we live in the Spirit, let us also walk in the Spirit".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:20
verses.text: "For we walk by faith, not by sight," the noble apostle says.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:21
verses.text: Within the veil, then, is concealed the sacerdotal service; and it keeps those engaged in it far from those without.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:22
verses.text: Again, there is the veil of the entrance into the holy of holies.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:23
verses.text: Four pillars there are, the sign of the sacred tetrad of the ancient covenants.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:24
verses.text: Further, the mystic name of four letters which was affixed to those alone to whom the adytum was accessible, is called Jave, which is interpreted, "Who is and shall be".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:25
verses.text: The name of God, too, among the Greeks contains four letters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:26
verses.text: Now the Lord, having come alone into the intellectual world, enters by His sufferings, introduced into the knowledge of the Ineffable, ascending above every name which is known by sound.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:27
verses.text: The lamp, too, was placed to the south of the altar of incense; and by it were shown the motions of the seven planets, that perform their revolutions towards the south.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:28
verses.text: For three branches rose on either side of the lamp, and lights on them; since also the sun, like the lamp, set in the midst of all the planets, dispenses with a kind of divine music the light to those above and to those below.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:29
verses.text: The golden lamp conveys another enigma as a symbol of Christ, not in respect of form alone, but in his casting light, "at sundry times and divers manners," on those who believe on Him and hope, and who see by means of the ministry of the First-born.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:30
verses.text: And they say that the seven eyes of the Lord "are the seven spirits resting on the rod that springs from the root of Jesse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:31
verses.text: North of the altar of incense was placed a table, on which there was "the exhibition of the loaves;" for the most nourishing of the winds are those of the north.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:32
verses.text: And thus are signified certain seats of churches conspiring so as to form one body and one assemblage.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:33
verses.text: And the things recorded of the sacred ark signify the properties of the world of thought, which is hidden and closed to the many.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:34
verses.text: And those golden figures, each of them with six wings, signify either the two bears, as some will have it, or rather the two hemispheres.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:35
verses.text: And the name cherubim meant "much knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:36
verses.text: But both together have twelve wings, and by the zodiac and time, which moves on it, point out  the world of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:37
verses.text: It is of them, I think, that Tragedy, discoursing of Nature, says:—  "Unwearied Time circles full in perennial flow, Producing itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:38
verses.text: And the twin-bears On the swift wandering motions of their wings, Keep the Atlantean pole".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:39
verses.text: And Atlas, the unsuffering pole, may mean the fixed sphere, or better perhaps, motionless eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:40
verses.text: But I think it better to regard the ark, so called from the Hebrew word Thebotha, as signifying something else.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:41
verses.text: It is interpreted, one instead of one in all places.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:42
verses.text: Whether, then, it is the eighth region and the world of thought, or God, all-embracing, and without shape, and invisible, that is indicated, we may for the present defer saying.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:43
verses.text: But it signifies the repose which dwells with the adoring spirits, which are meant by the cherubim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:44
verses.text: For He who prohibited the making of a graven image, would never Himself have made an image in the likeness of holy things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:45
verses.text: Nor is there at all any composite thing, and creature endowed with sensation, of the sort in heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:46
verses.text: But the face is a symbol of the rational soul, and the wings are the lofty ministers and energies of powers right and left; and the voice is delightsome glory in ceaseless contemplation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:47
verses.text: Let it suffice that the mystic interpretation has advanced so far.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:48
verses.text: Now the high priest's robe is the symbol of the world of sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:49
verses.text: The seven planets are represented by the five stones and the two carbuncles, for Saturn and the Moon.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:50
verses.text: The former is southern, and moist, and earthy, and heavy; the latter aerial, whence she is called by some Artemis, as if aerotomos (cutting the air); and the air is cloudy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:51
verses.text: And cooperating as they did in the production of things here below, those that by Divine Providence are set over the planets are rightly represented as placed on the breast and shoulders; and by them was the work of creation, the first week.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:52
verses.text: And the breast is the seat of the heart and soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:53
verses.text: Differently, the stones might be the various phases of salvation; some occupying the upper, some the lower parts of the entire body saved.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:54
verses.text: The three hundred and sixty bells, suspended from the robe, is the space of a year, "the acceptable year of the Lord," proclaiming and resounding the stupendous manifestation of the Saviour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:55
verses.text: Further, the broad gold mitre indicates the regal power of the Lord, "since the Head of the Church" is the Savour.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:56
verses.text: The mitre that is on it i-e:, the head is, then, a sign of most princely rule; and otherwise we have heard it said, "The Head of Christ is the God and Father of our Lord Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:57
verses.text: Moreover, there was the breastplate, comprising the ephod, which is the symbol of work, and the oracle (λογίον); and this indicated the Word (λόγος) by which it was framed, and is the symbol of heaven, made by the Word, and subjected to Christ, the Head of all things, inasmuch as it moves in the same way, and in a like manner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:58
verses.text: The luminous emerald stones, therefore, in the ephod, signify the sun and moon, the helpers of nature.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:59
verses.text: The shoulder, I take it, is the commencement of the hand.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:60
verses.text: The twelve stones, set in four rows on the breast, describe for us the circle of the zodiac, in the four changes of the year.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:61
verses.text: It was otherwise requisite that the law and the prophets should be placed beneath the Lord's head, because in both Testaments mention is made of the righteous.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:62
verses.text: For were we to say that the apostles were at once prophets and righteous, we should say well, "since one and the self-same Holy Spirit works in all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:63
verses.text: And as the Lord is above the whole world, yea, above the world of thought, so the name engraven on the plate has been regarded to signify, above all rule and authority; and it was inscribed with reference both to the written commandments and the manifestation to sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:64
verses.text: And it is the name of God that is expressed; since, as the Son sees the goodness of the Father, God the Saviour works, being called the first principle of all things, which was imaged forth from the invisible God first, and before the ages, and which fashioned all things which came into being after itself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:65
verses.text: Nay more, the oracle exhibits the prophecy which by the Word cries and preaches, and the judgment that is to come; since it is the same Word which prophesies, and judges, and discriminates all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:66
verses.text: And they say that the robe prophesied the ministry in the flesh, by which He was seen in closer relation to the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:67
verses.text: So the high priest, putting off his consecrated robe (the universe, and the creation in the universe, were consecrated by Him assenting that, what was made, was good), washes himself, and puts on the other tunic—a holy-of-holies one, so to speak—which is to accompany him into the adytum; exhibiting, as seems to me, the Levite and Gnostic, as the chief of other priests (those bathed in water, and clothed in faith alone, and expecting their own individual abode), himself distinguishing the objects of the intellect from the things of sense, rising above other priests,  hasting to the entrance to the world of ideas, to wash himself from the things here below, not in water, as formerly one was cleansed on being enrolled in the tribe of Levi.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:68
verses.text: But purified already by the gnostic Word in his whole heart, and thoroughly regulated, and having improved that mode of life received from the priest to the highest pitch, being quite sanctified both in word and life, and having put on the bright array of glory, and received the ineffable inheritance of that spiritual and perfect man, "which eye hath not seen and ear hath not heard, and it hath not entered into the heart of man;" and having become son and friend, he is now replenished with insatiable contemplation face to face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:69
verses.text: For there is nothing like hearing the Word Himself, who by means of the Scripture inspires fuller intelligence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:70
verses.text: For so it is said, "And he shall put off the linen robe, which he had put on when he entered into the holy place; and shall lay it aside there, and wash his body in water in the holy place, and put on his robe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:71
verses.text: But in one way, as I think, the Lord puts off and puts on by descending into the region of sense; and in another, he who through Him has believed puts off and puts on, as the apostle intimated, the consecrated stole.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 7:72
verses.text: Thence, after the image of the Lord the worthiest were chosen from the sacred tribes to be high priests, and those elected to the kingly office and to prophecy were anointed.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 7—The Egyptian Symbols and Enigmas of Sacred Things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:2
verses.text: Whence also the Egyptians did not entrust the mysteries they possessed to all and sundry, and did not divulge the knowledge of divine things to the profane; but only to those destined to ascend the throne, and those of the priests that were judged the worthiest, from their nurture, culture, and birth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:3
verses.text: Similar, then, to the Hebrew enigmas in respect to concealment, are those of the Egyptians also.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:4
verses.text: Of the Egyptians, some show the sun on a ship, others on a crocodile.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:5
verses.text: And they signify hereby, that the sun, making a passage through the delicious and moist air, generates time; which is symbolized by the crocodile in some other sacerdotal account.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:6
verses.text: Further, at Diospolis in Egypt, on the temple called Pylon, there was figured a boy as the symbol of production, and an old man as that of decay.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:7
verses.text: A hawk, on the other hand, was the symbol of God, as a fish of hate; and, according to a different symbolism, the crocodile of impudence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:8
verses.text: The whole symbol, then, when put together, appears to teach this: "Oh ye who are born and die, God hates impudence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:9
verses.text: And there are those who fashion ears and eyes of costly material, and consecrate them, dedicating them in the temples to the gods—by this plainly indicating that God sees and hears all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:10
verses.text: Besides, the lion is with them the symbol of strength and prowess, as the ox clearly is of the earth itself, and husbandry and food, and the horse of fortitude and confidence; while, on the other hand, the sphinx, of strength combined with intelligence—as it had a body entirely that of a lion, and the face of a man.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:11
verses.text: Similarly to these, to indicate intelligence, and memory, and power, and art, a man is sculptured in the temples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:12
verses.text: And in what is called among them the Komasiae of the gods, they carry about golden images—two dogs, one hawk, and one ibis; and the four figures of the images they call four letters.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:13
verses.text: For the dogs are symbols of the two hemispheres, which, as it were, go round and keep watch; the hawk, of the sun, for it is fiery and destructive (so they attribute pestilential diseases to the sun); the ibis, of the moon, likening the shady parts to that which is dark in plumage, and the luminous to the light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:14
verses.text: And some will have it that by the dogs are meant the tropics, which guard and watch the sun's passage to the south and north.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:15
verses.text: The hawk signifies the equinoctial line, which is high and parched with heat, as the ibis the ecliptic.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 8:16
verses.text: For the ibis seems, above other animals, to have furnished to the Egyptians the first rudiments of the invention of number and measure, as the oblique line did of circles.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 8—The Use of the Symbolic Style by Poets and Philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:2
verses.text: But it was not only the most highly intellectual of the Egyptians, but also such of other barbarians as prosecuted philosophy, that affected the symbolical style.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:3
verses.text: They say, then, that Idanthuris king of the Scythians, as Pherecydes of Syros relates, sent to Darius, on his passing the Ister in threat of war, a symbol, instead of a letter, consisting of a mouse, a frog, a bird, a javelin, a plough.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:4
verses.text: And there being a doubt in reference to them, as was to be expected, Orontopagas the Chiliarch said that they were to resign the kingdom; taking dwellings to be meant by the mouse, waters by the frog, air by the bird, land by the plough, arms by the javelin.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:5
verses.text: But Xiphodres interpreted the contrary; for he said, "If we do not take our flight like birds, or like mice get below the earth, or like frogs beneath the water, we shall not escape their arrows; for we are not lords of the territory".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:6
verses.text: It is said that Anacharsis the Scythian, while asleep, covered the pudenda with his left hand, and his mouth with his right, to intimate that both ought to be mastered, but that it was a greater thing to master the tongue than voluptuousness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:7
