verses.text: And why should I linger over the barbarians, when I can adduce the Greeks as exceedingly addicted to the use of the method of concealment? Androcydes the Pythagorean says the far-famed so-called Ephesian letters were of the class of symbols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:8
verses.text: For he said that ἄσκιον (shadowless) meant darkness, for it has no shadow; and κατάσκιον (shadowy) light, since it casts with its rays the shadow; and λίξ if is the earth, according to an ancient' appellation; and τετράς is the year, in reference to the seasons; and δαμναμενεύς is the sun, which overpowers (δαμάζων); and τὰ αἴσια is the true voice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:9
verses.text: And then the symbol intimates that divine things have been arranged in harmonious order—darkness to light, the sun to the year, and the earth to nature's processes of production of every sort.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:10
verses.text: Also Dionysius Thrax, the grammarian, in his book, Respecting the Exposition of the Symbolical Signification in Circles, says expressly, "Some signified actions not by words only, but also by symbols: by words, as is the case of what are called the Delphic maxims, 'Nothing in excess,' 'Know thyself,' and the like; and by symbols, as the wheel that is turned in the temples of the gods, derived from the Egyptians, and the branches that are given to the worshippers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:11
verses.text: For the Thracian Orpheus says:—  "Whatever works of branches are a care to men on earth, Not one has one fate in the mind, but all things Revolve around; and it is not lawful to stand at one point, But each one keeps an equal part of the race as they began".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:12
verses.text: The branches either stand as the symbol of the first food, or they are that the multitude may know that fruits spring and grow universally, remaining a very long time; but that the duration of life allotted to themselves is brief.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:13
verses.text: And it is on this account that they will have it that the branches are given; and perhaps also that they may know, that as these, on the other hand, are burned, so also they themselves speedily leave this life, and will become fuel for fire.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:14
verses.text: Very useful, then, is the mode of symbolic interpretation for many purposes; and it is helpful to the right theology, and to piety, and to the display of intelligence, and the practice of brevity, and the exhibition of wisdom.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:15
verses.text: "For the use of symbolical speech is characteristic of the wise man," appositely remarks the grammarian Didymus, "and the explanation of what is signified by it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:16
verses.text: And indeed the most elementary instruction of children embraces the interpretation of the four elements; for it is said that the Phrygians call water Bedu, as also Orpheus says:—  "And bright water is poured down, the Bedu of the nymphs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:17
verses.text: Dion Thytes also seems to write similarly:—  And taking Bedu, pour it on your hands, and turn to divination".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:18
verses.text: On the other hand, the comic poet, Philydeus, understands by Bedu the air, as being (Biodoros) life-giver, in the following lines:—  "I pray that I may inhale the salutary Bedu, Which is the most essential part of health; Inhale the pure, the unsullied air".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:19
verses.text: In the same opinion also concurs Neanthes of Cyzicum, who writes that the Macedonian priests invoke Bedu, which they interpret to mean the air, to be propitious to them and to their children.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:20
verses.text: And Zaps some have ignorantly taken for fire (from ζέσιν, boiling); for so the sea is called, as Euphorion, in his reply to Theoridas:—  "And Zaps, destroyer of ships, wrecked it on the rocks".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:21
verses.text: And Dionysius Iambus similarly:—  "Briny Zaps moans about the maddened deep".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:22
verses.text: Similarly Cratinus the younger, the comic poet:—  "Zaps casts forth shrimps and little fishes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:23
verses.text: And Simmias of Rhodes:—  "Parent of the Ignetes and the Telchines briny Zaps was born".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:24
verses.text: And χθών is the earth (κεχυμένη) spread forth to bigness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:25
verses.text: And Plectron, according to some, is the sky (πόλος), according to others, it is the air, which strikes (πλήσσοντα) and moves to nature and increase, and which fills all things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:26
verses.text: But these have not read Cleanthes the philosopher, who expressly calls Plectron the sun; for darting his beams in the east, as if striking the world, he leads the light to its harmonious course.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:27
verses.text: And from the sun it signifies also the rest of the stars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:28
verses.text: And the Sphinx is not the comprehension of the universe, and the revolution of the world, according to the poet Aratus; but perhaps it is the spiritual tone which pervades and holds together the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:29
verses.text: But it is better to regard it as the ether, which holds together and presses all things; as also Empedocles says:—  "But come now, first will I speak of the Sun, the first principle of all things, From which all, that we look upon, has sprung, Both earth, and billowy deep, and humid air; Titan and Ether too, which binds all things around".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:30
verses.text: And Apollodorus of Corcyra says that these lines were recited by Branchus the seer, when purifying the Milesians from plague; for he, sprinkling  the multitude with branches of laurel, led off the hymn somehow as follows:—  "Sing Boys Hecaergus and Hecaerga".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:31
verses.text: And the people accompanied him, saying, "Bedu, Zaps, Chthon, Plectron, Sphinx, Cnaxzbi, Chthyptes, Phlegmos, Drops".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:32
verses.text: Callimachus relates the story in iambics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:33
verses.text: Cnaxzbi is, by derivation, the plague, from its gnawing (κναίειν) and destroying (διαφθείρειν), and θῦψαι is to consume with a thunderbolt.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:34
verses.text: Thespis the tragic poet says that something else was signified by these, writing thus: "Lo, I offer to thee a libation of white Cnaxzbi, having pressed it from the yellow nurses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:35
verses.text: Lo, to thee, O two-horned Pan, mixing Chthyptes cheese with red honey, I place it on thy sacred altars.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:36
verses.text: Lo, to thee I pour as a libation the sparkling gleam of Bromius".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:37
verses.text: He signifies, as I think, the soul's first milk-like nutriment of the four-and-twenty elements, after which solidified milk comes as food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:38
verses.text: And last, he teaches of the blood of the vine of the Word, the sparkling wine, the perfecting gladness of instruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:39
verses.text: And Drops is the operating Word, which, beginning with elementary training, and advancing to the growth of the man, inflames and illumines man up to the measure of maturity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:40
verses.text: The third is said to be a writing copy for children—μάρπτες, σφίγξ, κλώψ, ζυνχθηδόν.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:41
verses.text: And it signifies, in my opinion, that by the arrangement of the elements and of the world, we must advance to the knowledge of what is more perfect, since eternal salvation is attained by force and toil; for μάρψαι is to grasp.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:42
verses.text: And the harmony of the world is meant by the Sphinx; and ζυνχθηδόν means difficulty; and κλώψς means at once the secret knowledge of the Lord and day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:43
verses.text: Well! does not Epigenes, in his book on the Poetry of Orpheus, in exhibiting the peculiarities found in Orpheus, say that by "the curved rods" (κεραίσι) is meant "ploughs;" and by the warp (στήμοσι), the furrows; and the woof (μίτος) is a figurative expression for the seed; and that the tears of Zeus signify a shower; and that the "parts" (μοῖραι) are, again, the phases of the moon, the thirtieth day, and the fifteenth, and the new moon, and that Orpheus accordingly calls them "white-robed," as being parts of the light? Again, that the Spring is called "flowery," from its nature; and Night "still," on account of rest; and the Moon "Gorgonian," on account of the face in it; and that the time in which it is necessary to sow is called Aphrodite by the "Theologian".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:44
verses.text: In the same way, too, the Pythagoreans figuratively called the planets the "dogs of Persephone;" and to the sea they applied the metaphorical appellation of "the tears of Kronus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:45
verses.text: Myriads on myriads of enigmatical utterances by both poets and philosophers are to be found; and there are also whole books which present the mind of the writer veiled, as that of Heraclitus On Nature, who on this very account is called "Obscure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:46
verses.text: Similar to this book is the Theology of Pherecydes of Syrus; for Euphorion the poet, and the Causes of Callimachus, and the Alexandra of Lycophron, and the like, are proposed as an exercise in exposition to all the grammarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:47
verses.text: It is, then, proper that the Barbarian philosophy, on which it is our business to speak, should prophecy also obscurely and by symbols, as was evinced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:48
verses.text: Such are the injunctions of Moses: "These common things, the sow, the hawk, the eagle, and the raven, are not to be eaten".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:49
verses.text: For the sow is the emblem of voluptuous and unclean lust of food, and lecherous and filthy licentiousness in venery, always prurient, and material, and lying in the mire, and fattening for slaughter and destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:50
verses.text: Again, he commands to eat that which parts the hoof and ruminates; "intimating," says Barnabas, "that we ought to cleave to those who fear the Lord, and meditate in their heart on that portion of the word which they have received, to those who speak and keep the Lord's statutes, to those to whom meditation is a work of gladness, and who ruminate on the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:51
verses.text: And what is the parted hoof? That the righteous walks in this world, and expects the holy eternity to come".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:52
verses.text: Then he adds, "See how well Moses enacted.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:53
verses.text: But whence could they understand or comprehend these things? We who have rightly understood speak the commandments as the Lord wished; wherefore He circumcised our ears and hearts, that we may comprehend these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:54
verses.text: And when he says, 'Thou shalt not eat the eagle, the hawk, the kite, and the crow;' he says, 'Thou shalt not adhere to or become like those men who know not how to procure for themselves subsistence by toil and sweat, but live by plunder, and lawlessly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:55
verses.text: ' For the eagle indicates robbery, the hawk injustice, and the raven greed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:56
verses.text: It is also written, 'With the innocent man thou wilt be innocent, and with the chosen choice, and with the perverse thou shall pervert.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:57
verses.text: ' It is incumbent on us to cleave to the saints, because they that cleave to them shall be sanctified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:58
verses.text: Thence Theognis writes:—  "For from the good you will learn good things; But if you mix with the bad, you will destroy any mind you may have".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:59
verses.text: And when, again, it is said in the ode, "For He hath triumphed gloriously: the horse and his rider hath He cast into the sea;" the many-limbed and brutal affection, lust, with the rider mounted, who gives the reins to pleasures, "He has cast into the sea," throwing them away into the disorders of the world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:60
verses.text: Thus also Plato, in his book On the Soul, says that the charioteer and the horse that ran off—the irrational part, which is divided in two, into anger and concupiscence—fall down; and so the myth intimates that it was through the licentiousness of the steeds that Phaëthon was thrown out.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:61
verses.text: Also in the case of Joseph: the brothers having envied this young man, who by his knowledge was possessed of uncommon foresight, stripped off the coat of many colours, and took and threw him into a pit (the pit was empty, it had no water), rejecting the good man's varied knowledge, springing from his love of instruction; or, in the exercise of the bare faith, which is according to the law, they threw him into the pit empty of water, selling him into Egypt, which was destitute of the divine word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:62
verses.text: And the pit was destitute of knowledge; into which being thrown and stript of his knowledge, he that had become unconsciously wise, stript of knowledge, seemed like his brethren.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:63
verses.text: Otherwise interpreted, the coat of many colours is lust, which takes its way into a yawning pit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:64
verses.text: "And if one open up or hew out a pit," it is said, "and do not cover it, and there fall in there a calf or ass, the owner of the pit shall pay the price in money, and give it to his neighbour; and the dead body shall be his.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:65
verses.text: Here add that prophecy: "The ox knoweth his owner, and the ass his master's crib: but Israel hath not understood Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:66
verses.text: In order, then, that none of those, who have fallen in with the knowledge taught by thee, may become incapable of holding the truth, and disobey and fall away, it is said, Be thou sure in the treatment of the word, and shut up the living spring in the depth from those who approach irrationally, but reach drink to those that thirst for truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:67
verses.text: Conceal it, then, from those who are unfit to receive the depth of knowledge, and so cover the pit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:68
verses.text: The owner of the pit, then, the Gnostic, shall himself be punished, incurring the blame of the others stumbling, and of being overwhelmed by the greatness of the word, he himself being of small capacity; or transferring the worker into the region of speculation, and on that account dislodging him from off-hand faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:69
verses.text: "And will pay money," rendering a reckoning, and submitting his accounts to the "omnipotent Will".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:70
verses.text: This, then, is the type of "the law and the prophets which were until John;" while he, though speaking more perspicuously as no longer prophesying, but pointing out as now present, Him, who was proclaimed symbolically from the beginning, nevertheless said, "I am not worthy to loose the latchet of the Lord's shoe".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:71
verses.text: For he confesses that he is not worthy to baptize so great a Power; for it behooves those, who purify others, to free the soul from the body and its sins, as the foot from the thong.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:72
verses.text: Perhaps also this signified the final exertion of the Saviour's power toward us—the immediate, I mean—that by His presence, concealed in the enigma of prophecy, inasmuch as he, by pointing out to sight Him that had been prophesied of, and indicating the Presence which had come, walking forth into the light, loosed the latchet of the oracles of the old economy, by unveiling the meaning of the symbols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:73
verses.text: And the observances practiced by the Romans in the case of wills have a place here; those balances and small coins to denote justice, and freeing of slaves, and rubbing of the ears.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 9:74
verses.text: For these observances are, that things may be transacted with justice; and those for the dispensing of honour; and the last, that he who happens to be near, as if a burden were imposed on him, should stand and hear and take the post of mediator.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 9—Reasons for Veiling the Truth in Symbols.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:2
verses.text: But, as appears, I have, in my eagerness to establish my point, insensibly gone beyond what is requisite.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:3
verses.text: For life would fail me to adduce the multitude of those who philosophize in a symbolical manner.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:4
verses.text: For the sake, then, of memory and brevity, and of attracting to the truth, such are the Scriptures of the Barbarian philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:5
verses.text: For only to those who often approach them, and have given them a trial by faith and in their whole life, will they supply the real philosophy and the true theology.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:6
verses.text: They also wish us to require an interpreter and guide.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:7
verses.text: For so they considered, that, receiving truth at the hands of those who knew it well, we would be more earnest and less liable to deception, and those worthy of them would profit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:8
verses.text: Besides, all things that shine through a veil show the truth grander and more imposing; as fruits shining through water, and figures through veils, which give added reflections to them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:9
verses.text: For, in addition to the fact that things unconcealed are perceived in one way, the rays of light shining round reveal defects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:10
verses.text: Since, then, we may draw several meanings, as we do from what is expressed in  veiled form, such being the case, the ignorant and unlearned man fails.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:11
verses.text: But the Gnostior apprehends.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:12
verses.text: Now, then, it is not wished that all things should be exposed indiscriminately to all and sundry, or the benefits of wisdom communicated to those who have not even in a dream been purified in soul, (for it is not allowed to hand to every chance comer what has been procured with such laborious efforts); nor are the mysteries of the word to be expounded to the profane.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:13
verses.text: They say, then, that Hipparchus the Pythagorean, being guilty of writing the tenets of Pythagoras in plain language, was expelled from the school, and a pillar raised for him as if he had been dead.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:14
verses.text: Wherefore also in the Barbarian philosophy they call those dead who have fallen away from the dogmas, and have placed the mind in subjection to carnal passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:15
verses.text: "For what fellowship hath righteousness and iniquity?" according to the divine apostle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:16
verses.text: "Or what communion hath light with darkness? or what concord hath Christ with Belial? or what portion hath the believer with the unbeliever?" For the honours of the Olympians and of mortals lie apart.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:17
verses.text: "Wherefore also go forth from the midst of them, and be separated, saith the Lord, and touch not the unclean thing; and I will receive you, and will be to you for a Father, and ye shall be my sons and daughters".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:18
verses.text: It was not only the Pythagoreans and Plato then, that concealed many things; but the Epicureans too say that they have things that may not be uttered, and do not allow all to peruse those writings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:19
verses.text: The Stoics also say that by the first Zeno things were written which they do not readily allow disciples to read, without their first giving proof whether or not they are genuine philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:20
verses.text: And the disciples of Aristotle say that some of their treatises are esoteric, and others common and exoteric.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:21
verses.text: Further, those who instituted the mysteries, being philosophers, buried their doctrines in myths, so as not to be obvious to all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:22
verses.text: Did they then, by veiling human opinions, prevent the ignorant from handling them; and was it not more beneficial for the holy and blessed contemplation of realities to be concealed? But it was not only the tenets of the Barbarian philosophy, or the Pythagorean myths.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:23
verses.text: But even those myths in Plato (in the Republic, that of Hero the Armenian; and in the Gorgias, that of aeacus and Rhadamanthus; and in the Phaedo, that of Tartarus; and in the Protagoras, that of Prometheus and Epimetheus; and besides these, that of the war between the Atlantini and the Athenians in the Atlanticum) are to be expounded allegorically, not absolutely in all their expressions, but in those which express the general sense.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:24
verses.text: And these we shall find indicated by symbols under the veil of allegory.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:25
verses.text: Also the association of Pythagoras, and the twofold intercourse with the associates which designates the majority, hearers (ἀκουσματικοί), and the others that have a genuine attachment to philosophy, disciples (μαθηματικοί), yet signified that something was spoken to the multitude, and something concealed from them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:26
verses.text: Perchance, too, the twofold species of the Peripatetic teaching—that called probable, and that called knowable—came very near the distinction between opinion on the one hand, and glory and truth on the other.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:27
verses.text: "To win the flowers of fair renown from men, Be not induced to speak aught more than right".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:28
verses.text: The Ionic muses accordingly expressly say, "That the majority of people, wise in their own estimation, follow minstrels and make use of laws, knowing that many are bad, few good; but that the best pursue glory: for the best make choice of the everlasting glory of men above all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:29
verses.text: But the multitude cram themselves like brutes, measuring happiness by the belly and the pudenda, and the basest things in us".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 10:30
verses.text: And the great Parmenides of Elea is introduced describing thus the teaching of the two ways:—  "The one is the dauntless heart of convincing truth; The other is in the opinions of men, in whom is no true faith".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 10—The Opinion of the Apostles on Veiling the Mysteries of the Faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:2
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, the divine apostle says, "By revelation the mystery was made known to me (as I wrote before in brief, in accordance with which, when ye read, ye may understand my knowledge in the mystery of Christ), which in other ages was not made known to the sons of men, as it is now revealed to His holy apostles and prophets".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:3
verses.text: For there is an instruction of the perfect, of which, writing to the Colossians, he says, "We cease not to pray for you, and beseech that ye may be filled with the knowledge of His will in all wisdom and spiritual understanding; that ye may walk worthy of the Lord to all pleasing; being fruitful in every good work, and increasing in the knowledge of God; strengthened with all might according to the glory of His power".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:4
verses.text: And again he says, "According to the disposition of the grace of God which is given me, that ye may fulfil the word of God; the mystery which has been hid from ages and generations, which now is manifested to His saints: to whom God wished to make known what is the riches of the glory of this mystery among the nations".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:5
verses.text: So that, on the one hand, then, are  the mysteries which were hid till the time of the apostles, and were delivered by them as they received from the Lord, and, concealed in the Old Testament, were manifested to the saints.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:6
verses.text: And, on the other hand, there is "the riches of the glory of the mystery in the Gentiles," which is faith and hope in Christ; which in another place he has called the "foundation".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:7
verses.text: And again, as if in eagerness to divulge this knowledge, he thus writes: "Warning every man in all wisdom, that we may present every man (the whole man) perfect in Christ;" not every man simply, since no one would be unbelieving.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:8
verses.text: Nor does he call every man who believes in Christ perfect; but he says all the man, as if he said the whole man, as if purified in body and soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:9
verses.text: For that the knowledge does not appertain to all, he expressly adds: "Being knit together in love, and unto all the riches of the full assurance of knowledge, to the acknowledgment of the mystery of God in Christ, in whom are hid all the treasures of wisdom and of knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:10
verses.text: "Continue in prayer, watching therein with thanksgiving".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:11
verses.text: And thanksgiving has place not for the soul and spiritual blessings alone, but also for the body, and for the good things of the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:12
verses.text: And he still more clearly reveals that knowledge belongs not to all, by adding: "Praying at the same time for you, that God would open to us a door to speak the mystery of Christ, for which I am bound; that I may make it known as I ought to speak".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:13
verses.text: For there were certainly, among the Hebrews, some things delivered unwritten.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:14
verses.text: "For when ye ought to be teachers for the time," it is said, as if they had grown old in the Old Testament, "ye have again need that one teach you which be the first principles of the oracles of God; and are become such as have need of milk, and not of solid food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:15
verses.text: For every one that partaketh of milk is unskilful in the word of righteousness; for he is a babe, being instructed with the first lessons.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:16
verses.text: But solid food belongs to those who are of full age, who by reason of use have their senses exercised so as to distinguish between good and evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:17
verses.text: Wherefore, leaving the first principles of the doctrine of Christ, let us go on to perfection".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:18
verses.text: Barnabas, too, who in person preached the word along with the apostle in the ministry of the Gentiles, says, "I write to you most simply, that ye may understand".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:19
verses.text: Then below, exhibiting already a clearer trace of gnostic tradition, he says, "What says the other prophet Moses to them? Lo, thus saith the Lord God, Enter ye into the good land which the Lord God sware, the God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob; and ye received for an inheritance that land, flowing with milk and honey".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:20
verses.text: What says knowledge? Learn, hope, it says, in Jesus, who is to be manifested to you in the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:21
verses.text: For man is the suffering land; for from the face of the ground was the formation of Adam.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:22
verses.text: What, then, does it say in reference to the good land, flowing with milk and honey? Blessed be our Lord, brethren, who has put into our hearts wisdom, and the understanding of His secrets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:23
verses.text: For the prophet says, "Who shall understand the Lord's parable but the wise and understanding, and he that loves his Lord?" It is but for few to comprehend these things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:24
verses.text: For it is not in the way of envy that the Lord announced in a Gospel, "My mystery is to me, and to the sons of my house;" placing the election in safety, and beyond anxiety; so that the things pertaining to what it has chosen and taken may be above the reach of envy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:25
verses.text: For he who has not the knowledge of good is wicked: for there is one good, the Father; and to be ignorant of the Father is death, as to know Him is eternal life, through participation in the power of the incorrupt One.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:26
verses.text: And to be incorruptible is to participate in divinity; but revolt from the knowledge of God brings corruption.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:27
verses.text: Again the prophet says: "And I will give thee treasures, concealed, dark, unseen; that they may know that I am the Lord".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:28
verses.text: Similarly David sings: "For, lo, Thou hast loved truth; the obscure and hidden things of wisdom hast Thou showed me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:29
verses.text: "Day utters speech to day" (what is clearly written), "and night to night proclaims knowledge" (which is hidden in a mystic veil); "and there are no words or utterances whose voices shall not be heard" by God, who said, "Shall one do what is secret, and I shall not see him?"  Wherefore instruction, which reveals hidden things, is called illumination, as it is the teacher only who uncovers the lid of the ark, contrary to what the poets say, that "Zeus stops up the jar of good things, but opens that of evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:30
verses.text: "For I know," says the apostle, "that when I come to you, I shall come in the fulness of the blessing of Christ;" designating the spiritual gift, and the gnostic communication, which being present he desires to impart to them present as "the fulness of Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery sealed in the ages of eternity, but now manifested by the prophetic Scriptures, according to the command of the eternal God, made known to all the nations, in order to the obedience of faith," that is, those  of the nations who believe that it is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:31
verses.text: But only to a few of them is shown what those things are which are contained in the mystery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:32
verses.text: Rightly then, Plato, in the Epistles, treating of God, says: "We must speak in enigmas; that should the tablet come by any mischance on its leaves either by sea or land, he who reads may remain ignorant".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:33
verses.text: For the God of the universe, who is above all speech, all conception, all thought, can never be committed to writing, being inexpressible even by His own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:34
verses.text: And this too Plato showed, by saying: "Considering, then, these things, take care lest some time or other you repent on account of the present things, departing in a manner unworthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:35
verses.text: The greatest safeguard is not to write, but learn; for it is utterly impossible that what is written will not vanish".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:36
verses.text: Akin to this is what the holy Apostle Paul says, preserving the prophetic and truly ancient secret from which the teachings that were good were derived by the Greeks: "Howbeit we speak wisdom among them who are perfect; but not the wisdom of this world, or of the princes of this world, that come to nought; but we speak the wisdom of God hidden in a mystery".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:37
verses.text: Then proceeding, he thus inculcates the caution against the divulging of his words to the multitude in the following terms: "And I, brethren, could not speak to you as to spiritual, but as to carnal, even to babes in Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:38
verses.text: I have fed you with milk, not with meat: for ye were not yet able; neither are ye now able.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:39
verses.text: For ye are yet carnal".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:40
verses.text: If, then, "the milk" is said by the apostle to belong to the babes, and "meat" to be the food of the full-grown, milk will be understood to be catechetical instruction—the first food, as it were, of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:41
verses.text: And meat is the mystic contemplation; for this is the flesh and the blood of the Word, that is, the comprehension of the divine power and essence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:42
verses.text: "Taste and see that the Lord is Christ," it is said.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:43
verses.text: For so He imparts of Himself to those who partake of such food in a more spiritual manner; when now the soul nourishes itself, according to the truth-loving Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:44
verses.text: For the knowledge of the divine essence is the meat and drink of the divine Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:45
verses.text: Wherefore also Plato says, in the second book of the Republic, "It is those that sacrifice not a sow, but some great and difficult sacrifice," who ought to inquire respecting God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 11:46
verses.text: And the apostle writes, "Christ our passover was sacrificed for us;"—a sacrifice hard to procure, in truth, the Son of God consecrated for us.

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 11—Abstraction from Material Things Necessary in Order to Attain to the True Knowledge of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:2
verses.text: Now the sacrifice which is acceptable to God is unswerving abstraction from the body and its passions.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:3
verses.text: This is the really true piety.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:4
verses.text: And is not, on this account, philosophy rightly called by Socrates the practice of Death? For he who neither employs his eyes in the exercise of thought, nor draws aught from his other senses, but with pure mind itself applies to objects, practices the true philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:5
verses.text: This is, then, the import of the silence of five years prescribed by Pythagoras, which he enjoined on his disciples; that, abstracting themselves from the objects of sense, they might with the mind alone contemplate the Deity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:6
verses.text: It was from Moses that the chief of the Greeks drew these philosophical tenets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:7
verses.text: For he commands holocausts to be skinned and divided into parts.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:8
verses.text: For the gnostic soul must be consecrated to the light, stript of the integuments of matter, devoid of the frivolousness of the body and of all the passions, which are acquired through vain and lying opinions, and divested of the lusts of the flesh.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:9
verses.text: But the most of men, clothed with what is perishable, like cockles, and rolled all round in a ball in their excesses, like hedgehogs, entertain the same ideas of the blessed and incorruptible God as of themselves.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:10
verses.text: But it has escaped their notice, though they be near us, that God has bestowed on us ten thousand things in which He does not share: birth, being Himself unborn; food, He wanting nothing; and growth, He being always equal; and long life and immortality, He being immortal and incapable of growing old.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:11
verses.text: Wherefore let no one imagine that hands, and feet, and mouth, and eyes, and going in and coming out, and resentments and threats, are said by the Hebrews to be attributes of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:12
verses.text: By no means; but that certain of these appellations are used more sacredly in an allegorical sense, which, as the discourse proceeds, we shall explain at the proper time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:13
verses.text: "Wisdom of all medicines is the Panacea," writes Callimachus in the Epigrams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:14
verses.text: "And one becomes wise from another, both in past times and at present," says Bacchylides in the Poeans; "for it is not very easy to find the portals of unutterable words".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:15
verses.text: Beautifully, therefore, Isocrates writes in the Panathenaic, having put the question, "Who, then, are well trained?" adds, "First, those who manage well the things which occur each day, whose opinion jumps with opportunity, and is able for the most part to hit on what is beneficial; then those who behave becomingly and rightly to those who approach them, who take lightly and easily annoyances  and molestations offered by others, but conduct themselves as far as possible, to those with whom they have intercourse, with consummate care and moderation; further, those who have the command of their pleasures, and are not too much overcome by misfortunes, but conduct themselves in the midst of them with manliness, and in a way worthy of the nature which we share; fourth—and this is the greatest—those who are not corrupted by prosperity, and are not put beside themselves, or made haughty, but continue in the class of sensible people".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:16
verses.text: Then he puts on the top-stone of the discourse: "Those who have the disposition of their soul well suited not to one only of these things, but to them all—those I assert to be wise and perfect men, and to possess all the virtues".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:17
verses.text: Do you see how the Greeks deify the gnostic life (though not knowing how to become acquainted with it)? And what knowledge it is, they know not even in a dream.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:18
verses.text: If, then, it is agreed among us that knowledge is the food of reason, "blessed truly are they," according to the Scripture, "who hunger and thirst after truth: for they shall be filled" with everlasting food.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:19
verses.text: In the most wonderful harmony with these words, Euripides, the philosopher of the drama, is found in the following words,—making allusion, I know not how, at once to the Father and the Son:—  "To thee, the Lord of all, I bring Cakes and libations too, O Zeus, Or Hades would'st thou choose be called; Do thou accept my offering of all fruits, Rare, full, poured forth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:20
verses.text: For a whole burnt-offering and rare sacrifice for us is Christ.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:21
verses.text: And that unwittingly he mentions the Saviour, he will make plain, as he adds:—  "For thou who, 'midst the heavenly gods, Jove's sceptre sway'st, dost also share The rule of those on earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:22
verses.text: Then he says expressly:—  "Send light to human souls that fain would know Whence conflicts spring, and what the root of ills, And of the blessed gods to whom due rites Of sacrifice we needs must pay, that so We may from troubles find repose".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:23
verses.text: It is not then without reason that in the mysteries that obtain among the Greeks, lustrations hold the first place; as also the laver among the Barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:24
verses.text: After these are the minor mysteries, which have some foundation of instruction and of preliminary preparation for what is to come after; and the great mysteries, in which nothing remains to be learned of the universe, but only to contemplate and comprehend nature and things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:25
verses.text: We shall understand the mode of purification by confession, and that of contemplation by analysis, advancing by analysis to the first notion, beginning with the properties underlying it; abstracting from the body its physical properties, taking away the dimension of depth, then that of breadth, and then that of length.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:26
verses.text: For the point which remains is a unit, so to speak, having position; from which if we abstract position, there is the conception of unity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:27
verses.text: If, then, abstracting all that belongs to bodies and things called incorporeal, we cast ourselves into the greatness of Christ, and thence advance into immensity by holiness, we may reach somehow to the conception of the Almighty, knowing not what He is, but what He is not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:28
verses.text: And form and motion, or standing, or a throne, or place, or right hand or left, are not at all to be conceived as belonging to the Father of the universe, although it is so written.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:29
verses.text: But what each of these means will be shown in its proper place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:30
verses.text: The First Cause is not then in space, but above both space, and time, and name, and conception.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:31
verses.text: Wherefore also Moses says, "Show Thyself to me,"—intimating most clearly that God is not capable of being taught by man, or expressed in speech, but to be known only by His own power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:32
verses.text: For inquiry was obscure and dim; but the grace of knowledge is from Him by the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:33
verses.text: Most clearly Solomon shall testify to us, speaking thus: "The prudence of man is not in me: but God giveth me wisdom, and I know holy things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:34
verses.text: Now Moses, describing allegorically the divine prudence, called it the tree of life planted in Paradise; which Paradise may be the world in which all things proceeding from creation grow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:35
verses.text: In it also the Word blossomed and bore fruit, being "made flesh," and gave life to those "who had tasted of His graciousness;" since it was not without the wood of the tree that He came to our knowledge.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:36
verses.text: For our life was hung on it, in order that we might believe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:37
verses.text: And Solomon again says: "She is a tree of immortality to those who take hold of her".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:38
verses.text: "Behold, I set before thy face life and death, to love the Lord thy God, and to walk in His ways, and hear His voice, and trust in life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:39
verses.text: But if ye transgress the statutes and the judgments which I have given you, ye shall be destroyed with destruction.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:40
verses.text: For this is life, and the length of thy days, to love the Lord thy God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:41
verses.text: Again: "Abraham, when he came to the place which God told him of on the third day, looking up, saw the place afar off".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:42
verses.text: For the  first day is that which is constituted by the sight of good things; and the second is the soul's best desire; on the third, the mind perceives spiritual things, the eyes of the understanding being opened by the Teacher who rose on the third day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:43
verses.text: The three days may be the mystery of the seal, in which God is really believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:44
verses.text: It is consequently afar off that he sees the place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:45
verses.text: For the region of God is hard to attain; which Plato called the region of ideas, having learned from Moses that it was a place which contained all things universally.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:46
verses.text: But it is seen by Abraham afar off, rightly, because of his being in the realms of generation, and he is forthwith initiated by the angel.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:47
verses.text: Thence says the apostle: "Now we see as through a glass, but then face to face," by those sole pure and incorporeal applications of the intellect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:48
verses.text: In reasoning, it is possible to divine respecting God, if one attempt without any of the senses, by reason, to reach what is individual; and do not quit the sphere of existences, till, rising up to the things which transcend it, he apprehends by the intellect itself that which is good, moving in the very confines of the world of thought, according to Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:49
verses.text: Again, Moses, not allowing altars and temples to be constructed in many places, but raising one temple of God, announced that the world was only-begotten, as Basilides says, and that God is one, as does not as yet appear to Basilides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:50
verses.text: And since the gnostic Moses does not circumscribe within space Him that cannot be circumscribed, he set up no image in the temple to be worshipped; showing that God was invisible, and incapable of being circumscribed; and somehow leading the Hebrews to the conception of God by the honour for His name in the temple.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:51
verses.text: Further, the Word, prohibiting the constructing of temples and all sacrifices, intimates that the Almighty is not contained in anything, by what He says: "What house will ye build to Me? saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:52
verses.text: Heaven is my throne," and so on.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:53
verses.text: Similarly respecting sacrifices: "I do not desire the blood of bulls and the fat of lambs," and what the Holy Spirit by the prophet in the sequel forbids.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:54
verses.text: Most excellently, therefore, Euripides accords with these, when he writes:—  "What house constructed by the workmen's hands, With folds of walls, can clothe the shape divine?"  And of sacrifices he thus speaks:—  "For God needs nought, if He is truly God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:55
verses.text: These of the minstrels are the wretched myths".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:56
verses.text: "For it was not from need that God made the world; that He might reap honours from men and the other gods and demons, winning a kind of revenue from creation, and from us, fumes, and from the gods and demons, their proper ministries," says Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:57
verses.text: Most instructively, therefore, says Paul in the Acts of the Apostles: "The God that made the world, and all things in it, being the Lord of heaven and earth, dwelleth not in temples made with hands; neither is worshipped by men's hands, as if He needed anything; seeing that it is He Himself that giveth to all breath, and life, and all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:58
verses.text: And Zeno, the founder of the Stoic sect, says in this book of the Republic, "that we ought to make neither temples nor images; for that no work is worthy of the gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:59
verses.text: And he was not afraid to write in these very words: "There will be no need to build temples.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:60
verses.text: For a temple is not worth much, and ought not to be regarded as holy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:61
verses.text: For nothing is worth much, and holy, which is the work of builders and mechanics".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:62
verses.text: Rightly, therefore, Plato too, recognising the world as God's temple, pointed out to the citizens a spot in the city where their idols were to be laid up.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:63
verses.text: "Let not, then, any one again," he says, "consecrate temples to the gods.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:64
verses.text: For gold and silver in other states, in the case of private individuals and in the temples, is an invidious possession; and ivory, a body which has abandoned the life, is not a sacred votive offering; and steel and brass are the instruments of wars; but whatever one wishes to dedicate, let it be wood of one tree, as also stone for common temples".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:65
verses.text: Rightly, then, in the great Epistle he says: "For it is not capable of expression, like other branches of study.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:66
verses.text: But as the result of great intimacy with this subject, and living with it, a sudden light, like that kindled by a coruscating fire, arising in the soul, feeds itself".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 12:67
verses.text: Are not these statements like those of Zephaniah the prophet? "And the Spirit of the Lord took me, and brought me up to the fifth heaven, and I beheld angels called Lords; and their diadem was set on in the Holy Spirit; and each of them had a throne sevenfold brighter than the light of the rising sun; and they dwelt in temples of salvation, and hymned the ineffable, Most High God".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 12—God Cannot Be Embraced in Words or by the Mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:2
verses.text: "For both is it a difficult task to discover the Father and Maker of this universe; and having found Him, it is impossible to declare Him to all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:3
verses.text: For this is by no means capable of expression, like the other subjects of instruction," says the truth-loving Plato.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:4
verses.text: For he that had heard right well that the all-wise Moses, ascending the mount for holy contemplation, to the summit of  intellectual objects, necessarily commands that the whole people do not accompany him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:5
verses.text: And when the Scripture says, "Moses entered into the thick darkness where God was," this shows to those capable of understanding, that God is invisible and beyond expression by words.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:6
verses.text: And "the darkness"—which is, in truth, the unbelief and ignorance of the multitude—obstructs the gleam of truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:7
verses.text: And again Orpheus, the theologian, aided from this quarter, says:—  "One is perfect in himself, and all things are made the progeny of one,"  or, "are born;" for so also is it written.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:8
verses.text: He adds:—  "Him No one of mortals has seen, but He sees all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:9
verses.text: And he adds more clearly:—  "Him see I not, for round about, a cloud Has settled; for in mortal eyes are small, And mortal pupils—only flesh and bones grow there".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:10
verses.text: To these statements the apostle will testify: "I know a man in Christ, caught up into the third heaven, and thence into Paradise, who heard unutterable words which it is not lawful for a man to speak,"—intimating thus the impossibility of expressing God, and indicating that what is divine is unutterable by human power; if, indeed, he begins to speak above the third heaven, as it is lawful to initiate the elect souls in the mysteries there.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:11
verses.text: For I know what is in Plato (for the examples from the barbarian philosophy, which are many, are suggested now by the composition which, in accordance with promises previously given, waits the suitable time).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:12
verses.text: For doubting, in Timaeus, whether we ought to regard several worlds as to be understood by many heavens, or this one, he makes no distinction in the names, calling the world and heaven by the same name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:13
verses.text: But the words of the statement are as follows: "Whether, then, have we rightly spoken of one heaven, or of many and infinite? It were more correct to say one, if indeed it was created according to the model".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:14
verses.text: Further, in the Epistle of the Romans to the Corinthians it is written, "An ocean illimitable by men and the worlds after it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:15
verses.text: Consequently, therefore, the noble apostle exclaims, "Oh the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and the knowledge of God!"  And was it not this which the prophet meant, when he ordered unleavened cakes to be made, intimating that the truly sacred mystic word, respecting the unbegotten and His powers, ought to be concealed? In confirmation of these things, in the Epistle to the Corinthians the apostle plainly says: "Howbeit we speak wisdom among those who are perfect, but not the wisdom of this world, or of the princes of this world, that come to nought.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:16
verses.text: But we speak the wisdom of God hidden in a mystery".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:17
verses.text: And again in another place he says: "To the acknowledgment of the mystery of God in Christ, in whom are hid all the treasures of wisdom and knowledge".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:18
verses.text: These things the Saviour Himself seals when He says: "To you it is given to know the mysteries of the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:19
verses.text: And again the Gospel says that the Saviour spake to the apostles the word in a mystery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:20
verses.text: For prophecy says of Him: "He will open His mouth in parables, and will utter things kept secret from the foundation of the world".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:21
verses.text: And now, by the parable of the leaven, the Lord shows concealment; for He says, "The kingdom of heaven is like leaven, which a woman took and hid in three measures of meal, till the whole was leavened".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:22
verses.text: For the tripartite soul is saved by obedience, through the spiritual power hidden in it by faith; or because the power of the word which is given to us, being strong and powerful, draws to itself secretly and invisibly every one who receives it, and keeps it within himself, and brings his whole system into unity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:23
verses.text: Accordingly Solon has written most wisely respecting God thus:—  "It is most difficult to apprehend the mind's invisible measure Which alone holds the boundaries of all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:24
verses.text: For "the divine," says the poet of Agrigenturn,—  "Is not capable of being approached with our eyes, Or grasped with our hands; but the highway Of persuasion, highest of all, leads to men's minds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:25
verses.text: And John the apostle says: "No man hath seen God at any time.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:26
verses.text: The only-begotten God, who is in the bosom of the Father, He hath declared Him,"—calling invisibility and ineffableness the bosom of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:27
verses.text: Hence some have called it the Depth, as containing and embosoming all things, inaccessible and boundless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:28
verses.text: This discourse respecting God is most difficult to handle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:29
verses.text: For since the first principle of everything is difficult to find out, the absolutely first and oldest principle, which is the cause of all other things being and having been, is difficult to exhibit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:30
verses.text: For how can that be expressed which is neither genus, nor difference, nor species, nor individual, nor number; nay more, is  neither an event, nor that to which an event happens? No one can rightly express Him wholly.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:31
verses.text: For on account of His greatness He is ranked as the All, and is the Father of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:32
verses.text: Nor are any parts to be predicated of Him.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:33
verses.text: For the One is indivisible; wherefore also it is infinite, not considered with reference to inscrutability, but with reference to its being without dimensions, and not having a limit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:34
verses.text: And therefore it is without form and name.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:35
verses.text: And if we name it, we do not do so properly, terming it either the One, or the Good, or Mind, or Absolute Being, or Father, or God, or Creator, or Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:36
verses.text: We speak not as supplying His name; but for want, we use good names, in order that the mind may have these as points of support, so as not to err in other respects.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:37
verses.text: For each one by itself does not express God; but all together are indicative of the power of the Omnipotent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:38
verses.text: For predicates are expressed either from what belongs to things themselves, or from their mutual relation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:39
verses.text: But none of these are admissible in reference to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:40
verses.text: Nor any more is He apprehended by the science of demonstration.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:41
verses.text: For it depends on primary and better known principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:42
verses.text: But there is nothing antecedent to the Unbegotten.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:43
verses.text: It remains that we understand, then, the Unknown, by divine grace, and by the word alone that proceeds from Him; as Luke in the Acts of the Apostles relates that Paul said, "Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things ye are too superstitious.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:44
verses.text: For in walking about, and beholding the objects of your worship, I found an altar on which was inscribed, To the Unknown God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 13:45
verses.text: Whom therefore ye ignorantly worship, Him declare I unto you".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 13—The Knowledge of God a Divine Gift, According to the Philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:2
verses.text: Everything, then, which falls under a name, is originated, whether they will or not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:3
verses.text: Whether, then, the Father Himself draws to Himself everyone who has led a pure life, and has reached the conception of the blessed and incorruptible nature; or whether the free-will which is in us, by reaching the knowledge of the good, leaps and bounds over the barriers, as the gymnasts say; yet it is not without eminent grace that the soul is winged, and soars, and is raised above the higher spheres, laying aside all that is heavy, and surrendering itself to its kindred element.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:4
verses.text: Plato, too, in Meno, says that virtue is God-given, as the following expressions show: "From this argument then, O Meno, virtue is shown to come to those, in whom it is found, by divine providence".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:5
verses.text: Does it not then appear that "the gnostic disposition" which has come to all is enigmatically called "divine providence?" And he adds more explicitly: "If, then, in this whole treatise we have investigated well, it results that virtue is neither by nature, nor is it taught, but is produced by divine providence, not without intelligence, in those in whom it is found".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:6
verses.text: Wisdom which is God-given, as being the power of the Father, rouses indeed our free-will, and admits faith, and repays the application of the elect with its crowning fellowship.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:7
verses.text: And now I will adduce Plato himself, who clearly deems it fit to believe the children of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:8
verses.text: For, discoursing on gods that are visible and born, in Timaeus, he says: "But to speak of the other demons, and to know their birth, is too much for us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:9
verses.text: But we must credit those who have formerly spoken, they being the offspring of the gods, as they said, and knowing well their progenitors, although they speak without probable and necessary proofs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:10
verses.text: I do not think it possible that clearer testimony could be borne by the Greeks, that our Saviour, and those anointed to prophesy (the latter being called the sons of God, and the Lord being His own Son), are the true witnesses respecting divine things.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:11
verses.text: Wherefore also they ought to be believed, being inspired, he added.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:12
verses.text: And were one to say in a more tragic vein, that we ought not to believe,  "For it was not Zeus that told me these things,"  yet let him know that it was God Himself that promulgated the Scriptures by His Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:13
verses.text: And he, who announces what is his own, is to be believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:14
verses.text: "No one," says the Lord, "hath known the Father but the Son, and he to whom the Son shall reveal Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:15
verses.text: This, then, is to be believed, according to Plato, though it is announced and spoken "without probable and necessary proofs," but in the Old and New Testament.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:16
verses.text: "For except ye believe," says the Lord, "ye shall die in your sins".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:17
verses.text: And again: "He that believeth hath everlasting life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:18
verses.text: "Blessed are all they that put their trust in Him".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:19
verses.text: For trusting is more than faith.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:20
verses.text: For when one has believed that the Son of God is our teacher, he trusts that his teaching is true.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:21
verses.text: And as "instruction," according to Empedocles, "makes the mind grow," so trust in the Lord makes faith grow.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:22
verses.text: We say, then, that it is characteristic of the same persons to vilify philosophy, and run down faith, and to praise iniquity and felicitate a libidinous life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:23
verses.text: But now faith, if it is the voluntary assent of the soul, is still the doer of good things, the foundation of right conduct; and if Aristotle defines strictly when he teaches that ποιεῖν is applied to the irrational creatures and to inanimate  things, while πράττειν is applicable to men only, let him correct those who say that God is the maker (ποιητής) of the universe.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:24
verses.text: And what is done (πρακτόν), he says, is as good or as necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:25
verses.text: To do wrong, then, is not good, for no one does wrong except for some other thing; and nothing that is necessary is voluntary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:26
verses.text: To do wrong, then, is voluntary, so that it is not necessary.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:27
verses.text: But the good differ especially from the bad in inclinations and good desires.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:28
verses.text: For all depravity of soul is accompanied with want of restraint; and he who acts from passion, acts from want of restraint and from depravity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:29
verses.text: I cannot help admiring in every particular that divine utterance: "Verily, verily, I say unto you, He that entereth not in by the door into the sheepfold, but climbeth up some other way, the same is a thief and a robber.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:30
verses.text: But he that entereth in by the door is the shepherd of the sheep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:31
verses.text: To him the porter openeth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:32
verses.text: Then the Lord says in explanation, "I am the door of the sheep".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:33
verses.text: Men must then be saved by learning the truth through Christ, even if they attain philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:34
verses.text: For now that is clearly shown "which was not made known to other ages, which is now revealed to the sons of men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:35
verses.text: For there was always a natural manifestation of the one Almighty God, among all right-thinking men; and the most, who had not quite divested themselves of shame with respect to the truth, apprehended the eternal beneficence in divine providence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:36
verses.text: In fine, then, Xenocrates the Chalcedonian was not quite without hope that the notion of the Divinity existed even in the irrational creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:37
verses.text: And Democritus, though against his will, will make this avowal by the consequences of his dogmas; for he represents the same images as issuing, from the divine essence, on men and on the irrational animals.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:38
verses.text: Far from destitute of a divine idea is man, who, it is written in Genesis, partook of inspiration, being endowed with a purer essence than the other animate creatures.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:39
verses.text: Hence the Pythagoreans say that mind comes to man by divine providence, as Plato and Aristotle avow; but we assert that the Holy Spirit inspires him who has believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:40
verses.text: The Platonists hold that mind is an effluence of divine dispensation in the soul, and they place the soul in the body.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:41
verses.text: For it is expressly said by Joel, one of the twelve prophets, "And it shall come to pass after these things, I will pour out of My Spirit on all flesh, and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:42
verses.text: But it is not as a portion of God that the Spirit is in each of us.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:43
verses.text: But how this dispensation takes place, and what the Holy Spirit is, shall be shown by us in the books on prophecy, and in those on the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 14:44
verses.text: But "incredulity is good at concealing the depths of knowledge," according to Heraclitus; "for incredulity escapes from ignorance".

chapters.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 14—Greek Plagiarism from the Hebrews.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:2
verses.text: Let us add in completion what follows, and exhibit now with greater clearness the plagiarism of the Greeks from the Barbarian philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:3
verses.text: Now the Stoics say that God, like the soul, is essentially body and spirit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:4
verses.text: You will find all this explicitly in their writings.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:5
verses.text: Do not consider at present their allegories as the gnostic truth presents them; whether they show one thing and mean another, like the dexterous athletes.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:6
verses.text: Well, they say that God pervades all being; while we call Him solely Maker, and Maker by the Word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:7
verses.text: They were misled by what is said in the book of Wisdom: "He pervades and passes through all by reason of His purity;" since they did not understand that this was said of Wisdom, which was the first of the creation of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:8
verses.text: So be it, they say.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:9
verses.text: But the philosophers, the Stoics, and Plato, and Pythagoras, nay more, Aristotle the Peripatetic, suppose the existence of matter among the first principles; and not one first principle.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:10
verses.text: Let them then know that what is called matter by them, is said by them to be without quality, and without form, and more daringly said by Plato to be non-existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:11
verses.text: And does he not say very mystically, knowing that the true and real first cause is one, in these very words: "Now, then, let our opinion be so.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:12
verses.text: As to the first principle or principles of the universe, or what opinion we ought to entertain about all these points, we are not now to speak, for no other cause than on account of its being difficult to explain our sentiments in accordance with the present form of discourse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:13
verses.text: But undoubtedly that prophetic expression, "Now the earth was invisible and formless," supplied them with the ground of material essence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:14
verses.text: And the introduction of "chance" was hence suggested to Epicurus, who misapprehended the statement, "Vanity of vanities, and all is vanity".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:15
verses.text: And it occurred to Aristotle to extend Providence as far as the moon from this psalm: "Lord, Thy mercy is in the heavens; and Thy truth reacheth to the clouds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:16
verses.text: For the explanation of the prophetic mysteries had not yet been revealed previous to the advent of the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:17
verses.text: Punishments after death, on the other hand, and penal retribution by fire, were pilfered from the Barbarian philosophy both by all the poetic Muses and by the Hellenic philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:18
