verses.text: Plato,  accordingly, in the last book of the Republic, says in these express terms: "Then these men fierce and fiery to look on, standing by, and hearing the sound, seized and took some aside; and binding Aridaeus and the rest hand, foot, and head, and throwing them down, and flaying them, dragged them along the way, tearing their flesh with thorns".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:19
verses.text: For the fiery men are meant to signify the angels, who seize and punish the wicked.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:20
verses.text: "Who maketh," it is said, "His angels spirits; His ministers flaming fire".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:21
verses.text: It follows from this that the soul is immortal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:22
verses.text: For what is tortured or corrected being in a state of sensation lives, though said to suffer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:23
verses.text: Well! Did not Plato know of the rivers of fire and the depth of the earth, and Tartarus, called by the Barbarians Gehenna, naming, as he does prophetically, Cocytus, and Acheron, and Pyriphlegethon, and introducing such corrective tortures for discipline?  But indicating "the angels" as the Scripture says, "of the little ones, and of the least, which see God," and also the oversight reaching to us exercised by the tutelary angels, he shrinks not from writing, "That when all the souls have selected their several lives, according as it has fallen to their lot, they advance in order to Lachesis; and she sends along with each one, as his guide in life, and the joint accomplisher of his purposes, the demon which he has chosen".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:24
verses.text: Perhaps also the demon of Socrates suggested to him something similar.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:25
verses.text: Nay, the philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:26
verses.text: having so heard from Moses, taught that the world was created.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:27
verses.text: And so Plato expressly said, "Whether was it that the world had no beginning of its existence, or derived its beginning from some beginning? For being visible, it is tangible; and being tangible, it has a body".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:28
verses.text: Again, when he says, "It is a difficult task to find the Maker and Father of this universe," he not only showed that the universe was created, but points out that it was generated by him as a son, and that he is called its father, as deriving its being from him alone, and springing from non-existence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:29
verses.text: The Stoics, too, hold the tenet that the world was created.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:30
verses.text: And that the devil so spoken of by the Barbarian philosophy, the prince of the demons, is a wicked spirit, Plato asserts in the tenth book of the Laws, in these words: "Must we not say that spirit which pervades the things that are moved on all sides, pervades also heaven? Well, what? One or more? Several, say I, in reply for you.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:31
verses.text: Let us not suppose fewer than two—that which is beneficent, and that which is able to accomplish the opposite".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:32
verses.text: Similarly in the Phoedrus he writes as follows: "Now there are other evils.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:33
verses.text: But some demon has mingled pleasure with the most things at present".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:34
verses.text: Further, in the tenth book of the Laws, he expressly emits that apostolic sentiment, "Our contest is not with flesh and blood, but principalities, with powers, with the spiritual things of those which are in heaven;" writing thus: "For since we are agreed that heaven is full of many good beings; but it is also full of the opposite of these, and more of these; and as we assert such a contest is deathless, and requiring marvellous watchfulness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:35
verses.text: Again the Barbarian philosophy knows the world of thought and the world of sense—the former archetypal, and the latter the image of that which is called the model; and assigns the former to the Monad, as being perceived by the mind, and the world of sense to the number six.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:36
verses.text: For six is called by the Pythagoreans marriage, as being the genital number; and he places in the Monad the invisible heaven and the holy earth, and intellectual light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:37
verses.text: For "in the beginning," it is said, "God made the heaven and the earth; and the earth was invisible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:38
verses.text: And it is added, "And God said, Let there be light; and there was light".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:39
verses.text: And in the material cosmogony He creates a solid heaven (and what is solid is capable of being perceived by sense), and a visible earth, and a light that is seen.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:40
verses.text: Does not Plato hence appear to have left the ideas of living creatures in the intellectual world, and to make intellectual objects into sensible species according to their genera? Rightly then Moses says, that the body which Plato calls "the earthly tabernacle" was formed of the ground, but that the rational soul was breathed by God into man's face.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:41
verses.text: For there, they say, the ruling faculty is situated; interpreting the access by the senses into the first man as the addition of the soul.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:42
verses.text: Wherefore also man is said "to have been made in God's image and likeness".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:43
verses.text: For the image of God is the divine and royal Word, the impassible man; and the image of the image is the human mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:44
verses.text: And if you wish to apprehend the likeness by another name, you will find it named in Moses, a divine correspondence.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:45
verses.text: For he says, "Walk after the Lord your God, and keep His commandments".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:46
verses.text: And I reckon all the virtuous, servants and followers of God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:47
verses.text: Hence the Stoics say that the end of philosophy is to live agreeable to nature; and Plato, likeness to God, as we have shown in the second Miscellany.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:48
verses.text: And Zeno the Stoic, borrowing from Plato, and he from the Barbarian philosophy, says that all the good are friends of one another.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:49
verses.text: For Socrates says in the Phoedrus, "that it has not been ordained that the bad should be a friend  to the bad, nor the good be not a friend to the good;" as also he showed sufficiently in the Lysis, that friendship is never preserved in wickedness and vice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:50
verses.text: And the Athenian stranger similarly says, "that there is conduct pleasing and conformable to God, based on one ancient ground-principle, That like loves like, provided it be within measure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:51
verses.text: But things beyond measure are congenial neither to what is within nor what is beyond measure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:52
verses.text: Now it is the case that God is the measure to us of all things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:53
verses.text: Then proceeding, Plato adds: "For every good man is like every other good man; and so being like to God, he is liked by every good man and by God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:54
verses.text: At this point I have just recollected the following.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:55
verses.text: In the end of the Timaeus he says: "You must necessarily assimilate that which perceives to that which is perceived, according to its original nature; and it is by so assimilating it that you attain to the end of the highest life proposed by the gods to men, for the present or the future time".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:56
verses.text: For those have equal power with these.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:57
verses.text: He, who seeks, will not stop till he find; and having found, he will wonder; and wondering, he will reign; and reigning, he will rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:58
verses.text: And what? Were not also those expressions of Thales derived from these? The fact that God is glorified for ever, and that He is expressly called by us the Searcher of hearts, he interprets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:59
verses.text: For Thales being asked, What is the divinity? said, What has neither beginning nor end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:60
verses.text: And on another asking, "If a man could elude the knowledge of the Divine Being while doing aught?" said, "How could he who cannot do so while thinking?"  Further, the Barbarian philosophy recognises good as alone excellent, and virtue as sufficient for happiness, when it says, "Behold, I have set before your eyes good and evil, life and death, that ye may choose life".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:61
verses.text: For it calls good, "life," and the choice of it excellent, and the choice of the opposite "evil".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:62
verses.text: And the end of good and of life is to become a lover of God: "For this is thy life and length of days," to love that which tends to the truth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:63
verses.text: And these points are yet clearer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:64
verses.text: For the Saviour, in enjoining to love God and our neighbour, says, "that on these two commandments hang the whole law and the prophets".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:65
verses.text: Such are the tenets promulgated by the Stoics; and before these, by Socrates, in the Phoedrus, who prays, "O Pan, and ye other gods, give me to be beautiful within".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:66
verses.text: And in the Theoetetus he says expressly, "For he that speaks well (καλῶς) is both beautiful and good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:67
verses.text: And in the Protagoras he avers to the companions of Protagoras that he has met with one more beautiful than Alcibiades, if indeed that which is wisest is most beautiful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:68
verses.text: For he said that virtue was the soul's beauty, and, on the contrary, that vice was the soul's deformity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:69
verses.text: Accordingly, Antipatrus the Stoic, who composed three books on the point, "That, according to Plato, only the beautiful is good," shows that, according to him, virtue is sufficient for happiness; and adduces several other dogmas agreeing with the Stoics.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:70
verses.text: And by Aristobulus, who lived in the time of Ptolemy Philadelphus, who is mentioned by the composer of the epitome of the books of the Maccabees, there were abundant books to show that the Peripatetic philosophy was derived from the law of Moses and from the other prophets.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:71
verses.text: Let such be the case.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:72
verses.text: Plato plainly calls us brethren, as being of one God and one teacher, in the following words: "For ye who are in the state are entirely brethren (as we shall say to them, continuing our story).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:73
verses.text: But the God who formed you, mixed gold in the composition of those of you who are fit to rule, at your birth, wherefore you are most highly honoured; and silver in the case of those who are helpers; and steel and brass in the case of farmers and other workers".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:74
verses.text: Whence, of necessity, some embrace and love those things to which knowledge pertains; and others matters of opinion.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:75
verses.text: Perchance he prophesies of that elect nature which is bent on knowledge; if by the supposition he makes of three natures he does not describe three politics, as some supposed: that of the Jews, the silver; that of the Greeks, the third; and that of the Christians, with whom has been mingled the regal gold, the Holy Spirit, the golden.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:76
verses.text: And exhibiting the Christian life, he writes in the Theaetetus in these words: "Let us now speak of the highest principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:77
verses.text: For why should we speak of those who make an abuse of philosophy? These know neither the way to the forum, nor know they the court or the senate-house, or any other public assembly of the state.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:78
verses.text: As for laws and decrees spoken or written, they neither see nor hear them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:79
verses.text: But party feelings of political associations and public meetings, and revels with musicians occupy them; but they never even dream of taking part in affairs.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:80
verses.text: Has any one conducted himself either well or ill in the state, or has aught evil descended to a man from his forefathers?—it escapes their attention as much as do the sands of the sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:81
verses.text: And the man does not even know that he does not know all these things; but in reality his body alone is situated and dwells in the state, while the man himself flies, according to Pindar, beneath the earth and above the sky, astronomizing, and exploring all nature on all sides.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:82
verses.text: Again, with the Lord's saying, "Let your yea be yea, and your nay nay," may be compared the following: "But to admit a falsehood, and destroy a truth, is in nowise lawful".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:83
verses.text: With the prohibition, also, against swearing agrees the saying in the tenth book of the Laws: "Let praise and an oath in everything be absent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:84
verses.text: And in general, Pythagoras, and Socrates, and Plato say that they hear God's voice while closely contemplating the fabric of the universe, made and preserved unceasingly by God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:85
verses.text: For they heard Moses say, "He said, and it was done," describing the word of God as an act.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:86
verses.text: And founding on the formation of man from the dust, the philosophers constantly term the body earthy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:87
verses.text: Homer, too, does not hesitate to put the following as an imprecation:—  "But may you all become earth and water".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:88
verses.text: As Esaias says, "And trample them down as clay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:89
verses.text: And Callimachus clearly writes:—  "That was the year in which Birds, fishes, quadrupeds, Spoke like Prometheus' clay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:90
verses.text: And the same again:—  "If thee Prometheus formed, And thou art not of other clay".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:91
verses.text: Hesiod says of Pandora:—  "And bade Hephaestus, famed, with all his speed, Knead earth with water, and man's voice and mind Infuse".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:92
verses.text: The Stoics, accordingly, define nature to be artificial fire, advancing systematically to generation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:93
verses.text: And God and His Word are by Scripture figuratively termed fire and light.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:94
verses.text: But how? Does not Homer himself, is not Homer himself, paraphrasing the retreat of the water from the land, and the clear uncovering of the dry land, when he says of Tethys and Oceanus:—  "For now for a long time they abstain from Each other's bed and love?"  Again, power in all things is by the most intellectual among the Greeks ascribed to God; Epicharmus—he was a Pythagorean—saying:—  "Nothing escapes the divine.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:95
verses.text: This it behoves thee to know.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:96
verses.text: He is our observer.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:97
verses.text: To God nought is impossible".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:98
verses.text: And the lyric poet:—  "And God from gloomy night Can raise unstained light, And can in darksome gloom obscure The day's refulgence pure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:99
verses.text: He alone who is able to make night during the period of day is God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:100
verses.text: In the Phoenomena Aratus writes thus:—  "With Zeus let us begin; whom let us ne'er, Being men, leave unexpressed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:101
verses.text: All full of Zeus, The streets, and throngs of men, and full the sea, And shores, and everywhere we Zeus enjoy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:102
verses.text: He adds:—  "For we also are His offspring;.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:103
verses.text: "  that is, by creation.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:104
verses.text: "Who, bland to men, Propitious signs displays, and to their tasks Arouses.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:105
verses.text: For these signs in heaven He fixed, The constellations spread, and crowned the year With stars; to show to men the seasons' tasks, That all things may proceed in order sure.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:106
verses.text: Him ever first, Him last too, they adore: Hail Father, marvel great—great boon to men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:107
verses.text: And before him, Homer, framing the world in accordance with Moses on the Vulcan-wrought shield, says:—  "On it he fashioned earth, and sky, and sea, And all the signs with which the heaven is crowned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:108
verses.text: For the Zeus celebrated in poems and prose compositions leads the mind up to God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:109
verses.text: And already, so to speak, Democritus writes, "that a few men are in the light, who stretch out their hands to that place which we Greeks now call the air.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:110
verses.text: Zeus speaks all, and he hears all, and distributes and takes away, and he is king of all".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:111
verses.text: And more mystically the Boeotian Pindar, being a Pythagorean, says:—  "One is the race of gods and men, And of one mother both have breath;"  that is, of matter: and names the one creator of these things, whom he calls Father, chief artificer, who furnishes the means of advancement on to divinity, according to merit.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:112
verses.text: For I pass over Plato; he plainly, in the Epistle to Erastus and Coriscus, is seen to exhibit the Father and Son somehow or other from the Hebrew Scriptures, exhorting in these words: "In invoking by oath, with not illiterate gravity, and with culture, the sister of gravity, God the author of all, and invoking Him by oath as the Lord, the Father of the Leader, and author; whom if ye study with a truly philosophical spirit, ye shall know".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:113
verses.text: And the address in the Timoeus calls the creator, Father, speaking thus: "Ye gods of gods, of whom I am Father; and the Creator of your works".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:114
verses.text: So that when he says, "Around the king of all, all things are, and because of Him are all things; and he or that is the cause of all good things; and around the second are the things second in order; and around the third, the third," I understand nothing else than the Holy Trinity to be meant; for the third is the Holy Spirit, and the Son is the second, by whom all things were made according to the will of the Father.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:115
verses.text: And the same, in the tenth book of the Republic, mentions Eros the son of Armenius, who is Zoroaster.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:116
verses.text: Zoroaster, then, writes: "These were composed by Zoroaster, the son of Armenius, a Pamphylian by birth: having died in battle, and been in Hades, I learned them of the gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:117
verses.text: This Zoroaster, Plato says, having been placed on the funeral pyre, rose again to life in twelve days.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:118
verses.text: He alludes perchance to the resurrection, or perchance to the fact that the path for souls to ascension lies through the twelve signs of the zodiac; and he himself says, that the descending pathway to birth is the same.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:119
verses.text: In the same way we are to understand the twelve labours of Hercules, after which the soul obtains release from this entire world.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:120
verses.text: I do not pass over Empedocles, who speaks thus physically of the renewal of all things, as consisting in a transmutation into the essence of fire, which is to take place.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:121
verses.text: And most plainly of the same opinion is Heraclitus of Ephesus, who considered that there was a world everlasting, and recognised one perishable—that is, in its arrangement, not being different from the former, viewed in a certain aspect.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:122
verses.text: But that he knew the imperishable world which consists of the universal essence to be everlastingly of a certain nature, he makes clear by speaking thus: "The same world of all things, neither any of the gods, nor any one of men, made.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:123
verses.text: But there was, and is, and will be ever-living fire, kindled according to measure, and quenched according to measure".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:124
verses.text: And that he taught it to be generated and perishable, is shown by what follows: "There are transmutations of fire,—first, the sea; and of the sea the half is land, the half fiery vapour".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:125
verses.text: For he says that these are the effects of power.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:126
verses.text: For fire is by the Word of God, which governs all things, changed by the air into moisture, which is, as it were, the germ of cosmical change; and this he calls sea.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:127
verses.text: And out of it again is produced earth, and sky, and all that they contain.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:128
verses.text: How, again, they are restored and ignited, he shows clearly in these words: "The sea is diffused and measured according to the same rule which subsisted before it became earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:129
verses.text: Similarly also respecting the other elements, the same is to be understood.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:130
verses.text: The most renowned of the Stoics teach similar doctrines with him, in treating of the conflagration and the government of the world, and both the world and man properly so called, and of the continuance of our souls.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:131
verses.text: Plato, again, in the seventh book of the Republic, has called "the day here nocturnal," as I suppose, on account of "the world-rulers of this darkness;" and the descent of the soul into the body, sleep and death, similarly with Heraclitus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:132
verses.text: And was not this announced, oracularly, of the Saviour, by the Spirit, saying by David, "I slept, and slumbered; I awoke: for the Lord will sustain me;" For He not only figuratively calls the resurrection of Christ rising from sleep; but to the descent of the Lord into the flesh he also applies the figurative term sleep.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:133
verses.text: The Saviour Himself enjoins, "Watch;" as much as to say, "Study how to live, and endeavour to separate the soul from the body".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:134
verses.text: And the Lord's day Plato prophetically speaks of in the tenth book of the Republic, in these words: "And when seven days have passed to each of them in the meadow, on the eighth they are to set out and arrive in four days".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:135
verses.text: By the meadow is to be understood the fixed sphere, as being a mild and genial spot, and the locality of the pious; and by the seven days each motion of the seven planets, and the whole practical art which speeds to the end of rest.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:136
verses.text: But after the wandering orbs the journey leads to heaven, that is, to the eighth motion and day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:137
verses.text: And he says that souls are gone on the fourth day, pointing out the passage through the four elements.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:138
verses.text: But the seventh day is recognised as sacred, not by the Hebrews only, but also by the Greeks; according to which the whole world of all animals and plants revolve.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:139
verses.text: Hesiod says of it:—  "The first, and fourth, and seventh day were held sacred".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:140
verses.text: And again:—  "And on the seventh the sun's resplendent orb".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:141
verses.text: And Homer:—  "And on the seventh then came the sacred day".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:142
verses.text: And:—  "The seventh was sacred".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:143
verses.text: And again:—  "It was the seventh day, and all things were accomplished".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:144
verses.text: And again:—  "And on the seventh morn we leave the stream of Acheron".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:145
verses.text: Callimachus the poet also writes:—  "It was the seventh morn, and they had all things done".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:146
verses.text: And again:—  "Among good days is the seventh day, and the seventh race".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:147
verses.text: And:—  "The seventh is among the prime, and the seventh is perfect".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:148
verses.text: And:—  "Now all the seven were made in starry heaven, In circles shining as the years appear".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:149
verses.text: The Elegies of Solon, too, intensely deify the seventh day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:150
verses.text: And how? Is it not similar to Scripture when it says, "Let us remove the righteous man from us, because he is troublesome to us?" when Plato, all but predicting the economy of salvation, says in the second book of the Republic as follows: "Thus he who is constituted just shall be scourged, shall be stretched on the rack, shall be bound, have his eyes put out; and at last, having suffered all evils, shall be crucified".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:151
verses.text: And the Socratic Antisthenes, paraphrasing that prophetic utterance, "To whom have ye likened me? saith the Lord," says that "God is like no one; wherefore no one can come to the knowledge of Him from an image".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:152
verses.text: Xenophon too, the Athenian, utters these similar sentiments in the following words: "He who shakes all things, and is Himself immoveable, is manifestly one great and powerful.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:153
verses.text: But what He is in form, appears not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:154
verses.text: No more does the sun, who wishes to shine in all directions, deem it right to permit any one to look on himself.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:155
verses.text: But if one gaze on him audaciously, he loses his eyesight".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:156
verses.text: "What flesh can see with eyes the Heavenly, True, Immortal God, whose dwelling is the poles? Not even before the bright beams of the sun Are men, as being mortal, fit to stand,"—  the Sibyl had said before.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:157
verses.text: Rightly, then, Xenophanes of Colophon, teaching that God is one and incorporeal, adds:—  "One God there is 'midst gods and men supreme; In form, in mind, unlike to mortal men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:158
verses.text: And again:—  "But men have the idea that gods are born, And wear their clothes, and have both voice and shape".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:159
verses.text: And again:—  "But had the oxen or the lions hands, Or could with hands depict a work like men, Were beasts to draw the semblance of the gods, The horses would them like to horses sketch, To oxen, oxen, and their bodies make Of such a shape as to themselves belongs".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:160
verses.text: Let us hear, then, the lyric poet Bacchylides speaking of the divine:—  "Who to diseases dire never succumb, And blameless are; in nought resembling men".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:161
verses.text: And also Cleanthes, the Stoic, who writes thus in a poem on the Deity:—  "If you ask what is the nature of the good, listen— That which is regular, just, holy, pious, Self-governing, useful, fair, fitting, Grave, independent, always beneficial, That feels no fear or grief, profitable, painless, Helpful, pleasant, safe, friendly, Held in esteem, agreeing with itself: honourable, Humble, careful, meek, zealous, Perennial, blameless, ever-during".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:162
verses.text: And the same, tacitly vilifying the idolatry of the multitude, adds:—  "Base is every one who looks to opinion, With the view of deriving any good from it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:163
verses.text: We are not, then, to think of God according to the opinion of the multitude.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:164
verses.text: "For I do not think that secretly, Imitating the guise of a scoundrel, He would go to thy bed as a man,"  says Amphion to Antiope.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:165
verses.text: And Sophocles plainly writes:—  "His mother Zeus espoused, Not in the likeness of gold, nor covered With swan's plumage, as the Pleuronian girl He impregnated; but an out and out man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:166
verses.text: He further proceeds, and adds:—  "And quick the adulterer stood on the bridal steps".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:167
verses.text: Then he details still more plainly the licentiousness of the fabled Zeus:—  "But he nor food nor cleansing water touched, But heart-stung went to bed, and that whole night Wantoned".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:168
verses.text: But let these be resigned to the follies of the theatre.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:169
verses.text: Heraclius plainly says: "But of the word which is eternal men are not able to understand, both before they have heard it, and on first hearing it".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:170
verses.text: And the lyrist Melanippides says in song:—  "Hear me, O Father, Wonder of men, Ruler of the ever-living soul".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:171
verses.text: And Parmenides the great, as Plato says in the Sophist, writes of God thus:—  "Very much, since unborn and indestructible He is, Whole, only-begotten, and immoveable, and unoriginated".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:172
verses.text: Hesiod also says:—  "For He of the immortals all is King and Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:173
verses.text: With God none else in might may strive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:174
verses.text: Nay more, Tragedy, drawing away from idols, teaches to look up to heaven.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:175
verses.text: Sophocles, as Hecataeus, who composed the histories in the work about Abraham and the Egyptians, says, exclaims plainly on the stage:—  "One in very truth, God is One, Who made the heaven and the far-stretching earth,  The Deep's blue billow, and the might of winds.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:176
verses.text: But of us mortals, many erring far In heart, as solace for our woes, have raised Images of gods—of stone, or else of brass, Or figures wrought of gold or ivory; And sacrifices and vain festivals To these appointing, deem ourselves devout".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:177
verses.text: And Euripides on the stage, in tragedy, says:—  "Dost thou this lofty, boundless Ether see, Which holds the earth around in the embrace Of humid arms? This reckon Zeus, And this regard as God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:178
verses.text: And in the drama of Pirithous, the same writes those lines in tragic vein:—  "Thee, self-sprung, who on Ether's wheel Hast universal nature spun, Around whom Light and dusky spangled Night, The countless host of stars, too, ceaseless dance".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:179
verses.text: For there he says that the creative mind is self-sprung.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:180
verses.text: What follows applies to the universe, in which are the opposites of light and darkness.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:181
verses.text: aeschylus also, the son of Euphorion, says with very great solemnity of God:—  "Ether is Zeus, Zeus earth, and Zeus the heaven; The universe is Zeus, and all above".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:182
verses.text: I am aware that Plato assents to Heraclitus, who writes: "The one thing that is wise alone will not be expressed, and means the name of Zeus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:183
verses.text: And again, "Law is to obey the will of one".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:184
verses.text: And if you wish to adduce that saying, "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear," you will find it expressed by the Ephesian to the following effect: "Those that hear without understanding are like the deaf.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:185
verses.text: The proverb witnesses against them, that when present they are absent".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:186
verses.text: But do you want to hear from the Greeks expressly of one first principle? Timaeus the Locrian, in the work on Nature, shall testify in the following words: "There is one first principle of all things unoriginated.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:187
verses.text: For were it originated, it would be no longer the first principle; but the first principle would be that from which it originated".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:188
verses.text: For this true opinion was derived from what follows: "Hear," it is said, "O Israel; the Lord thy God is one, and Him only shalt thou serve".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:189
verses.text: "Lo He all sure and all unerring is,"  says the Sibyl.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:190
verses.text: Homer also manifestly mentions the Father and the Son by a happy hit of divination in the following words:—  "If Outis, alone as thou art, offers thee violence, And there is no escaping disease sent by Zeus,— For the Cyclopes heed not aegis-bearing Zeus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:191
verses.text: And before him Orpheus said, speaking of the point in hand:—  "Son of great Zeus, Father of aegis-bearing Zeus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:192
verses.text: And Xenocrates the Chalcedonian, who mentions the supreme Zeus and the inferior Zeus, leaves an indication of the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:193
verses.text: Homer, while representing the gods as subject to human passions, appears to know the Divine Being, whom Epicurus does not so revere.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:194
verses.text: He says accordingly:—  "Why, son of Peleus, mortal as thou art, With swift feet me pursuest, a god Immortal? Hast thou not yet known That I am a god?"  For he shows that the Divinity cannot be captured by a mortal, or apprehended either with feet, or hands, or eyes, or by the body at all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:195
verses.text: "To whom have ye likened the Lord? or to what likeness have ye likened Him?" says the Scripture.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:196
verses.text: Has not the artificer made the image? or the goldsmith, melting the gold, has gilded it, and what follows.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:197
verses.text: The comic poet Epicharmus speaks in the Republic clearly of the Word in the following terms:—  "The life of men needs calculation and number alone, And we live by number and calculation, for these save mortals".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:198
verses.text: He then adds expressly:—  "Reason governs mortals, and alone preserves manners".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:199
verses.text: Then:—  "There is in man reasoning; and there is a divine Reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:200
verses.text: Reason is implanted in man to provide for life and sustenance, But divine Reason attends the arts in the case of all, Teaching them always what it is advantageous to do.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:201
verses.text: For it was not man that discovered art, but God brought it; And the Reason of man derives its origin from the divine Reason".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:202
verses.text: The Spirit also cries by Isaiah: "Wherefore the multitude of sacrifices? saith the Lord.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:203
verses.text: I am full of holocausts of rams, and the fat of lambs and the blood of bulls I wish not;" and a little after adds: "Wash you, and be clean.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:204
verses.text: Put away wickedness from your souls," and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:205
verses.text: Menander, the comic poet, writes in these very words:—  "If one by offering sacrifice, a crowd Of bulls or kids, O Pamphilus, by Zeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:206
verses.text: Or such like things; by making works of art, Garments of gold or purple, images  Of ivory or emerald, deems by these God can be made propitious, he does err, And has an empty mind.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:207
verses.text: For the man must prove A man of worth, who neither maids deflowers, Nor an adulterer is, nor steals, nor kills For love of worldly wealth, O Pamphilus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:208
verses.text: Nay, covet not a needle's thread.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:209
verses.text: For God Thee sees, being near beside thee"  "I am a God at hand," it is said by Jeremiah, "and not a God afar off.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:210
verses.text: Shall a man do aught in secret places, and I shall not see him?"  And again Menander, paraphrasing that Scripture, "Sacrifice a sacrifice of righteousness, and trust in the Lord," thus writes:—  "And not a needle even that is Another's ever covet, dearest friend; For God in righteous works delights, and so Permits him to increase his worldly wealth, Who toils, and ploughs the land both night and day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:211
verses.text: But sacrifice to God, and righteous be, Shining not in bright robes, but in thy heart; And when thou hear'st the thunder, do not flee, Being conscious to thyself of nought amiss, Good sir, for thee God ever present sees".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:212
verses.text: "Whilst thou art yet speaking," says the Scripture, "I will say, Lo, here I am".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:213
verses.text: Again Diphilus, the comic poet, discourses as, follows on the judgment:—  "Think'st thou, O Niceratus, that the dead, Who in all kinds of luxury in life have shared, Escape the Deity, as if forgot? There is an eye of justice, which sees all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:214
verses.text: For two ways, as we deem, to Hades lead— One for the good, the other for the bad.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:215
verses.text: But if the earth hides both for ever, then Go plunder, steal, rob, and be turbulent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:216
verses.text: But err not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:217
verses.text: For in Hades judgment is, Which God the Lord of all will execute, Whose name too dreadful is for me to name, Who gives to sinners length of earthly life.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:218
verses.text: If any mortal thinks, that day by day, While doing ill, he eludes the gods' keen sight, His thoughts are evil; and when justice has The leisure, he shall then detected be So thinking.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:219
verses.text: Look, whoe'er you be that say That there is not a God.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:220
verses.text: There is, there is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:221
verses.text: If one, by nature evil, evil does, Let him redeem the time; for such as he Shall by and by due punishment receive".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:222
verses.text: And with this agrees the tragedy in the following lines:—  "For there shall come, shall come that point of time, When Ether, golden-eyed, shall ope its store Of treasured fire; and the devouring flame, Raging, shall burn all things on earth below, And all above".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:223
verses.text: …  And after a little he adds:—  "And when the whole world fades, And vanished all the abyss of ocean's waves, And earth of trees is bare; and wrapt in flames, The air no more begets the winged tribes; Then He who all destroyed, shall all restore".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:224
verses.text: We shall find expressions similar to these also in the Orphic hymns, written as follows:—  "For having hidden all, brought them again To gladsome light, forth from his sacred heart, Solicitous".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:225
verses.text: And if we live throughout holily and righteously, we are happy here, and shall be happier after our departure hence; not possessing happiness for a time, but enabled to rest in eternity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:226
verses.text: "At the same hearth and table as the rest Of the immortal gods, we sit all free Of human ills, unharmed,"  says the philosophic poetry of Empedocles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:227
verses.text: And so, according to the Greeks, none is so great as to be above judgment, none so insignificant as to escape its notice.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:228
verses.text: And the same Orpheus speaks thus:—  "But to the word divine, looking, attend, Keeping aright the heart's receptacle Of intellect, and tread the straight path well, And only to the world's immortal King Direct thy gaze".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:229
verses.text: And again, respecting God, saying that He was invisible, and that He was known to but one, a Chaldean by race—meaning either by this Abraham or his son—he speaks as follows:—  "But one a scion of Chaldean race; For he the sun's path knew right well, And how the motion of the sphere about The earth proceeds, in circle moving Equally around its axis, how the winds Their chariot guide o'er air and sea".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:230
verses.text: Then, as if paraphrasing the expression, "Heaven is my throne, and earth is my footstool," he adds:—  "But in great heaven, He is seated firm Upon a throne of gold, and 'neath His feet The earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:231
verses.text: His right hand round the ocean's bound He stretches; and the hills' foundations shake To the centre at His wrath, nor can endure His mighty strength.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:232
verses.text: He all celestial is, And all things finishes upon the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:233
verses.text: He the Beginning, Middle is, and End.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:234
verses.text: But Thee I dare not speak.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:235
verses.text: In limbs And mind I tremble.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:236
verses.text: He rules from on high".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:237
verses.text: And so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:238
verses.text: For in these he indicates these prophetic utterances: "If Thou openest the heaven, trembling shall seize the mountains from Thy presence; and they shall melt, as wax melteth before the fire;" and in Isaiah, "Who hath measured the heaven with a span, and the whole earth with His fist? Again, when it is said:—  "Ruler of Ether, Hades, Sea, and Land, Who with Thy bolts Olympus' strong-built home Dost shake.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:239
verses.text: Whom demons dread, and whom the throng Of gods do fear.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:240
verses.text: Whom, too, the Fates obey, Relentless though they be.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:241
verses.text: O deathless One, Our mother's Sire! whose wrath makes all things reel; Who mov'st the winds, and shroud'st in clouds the world, Broad Ether cleaving with Thy lightning gleams,— Thine is the order 'mongst the stars, which run As Thine unchangeable behests direct.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:242
verses.text: Before Thy burning throne the angels wait, Much-working, charged to do all things, for men.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:243
verses.text: Thy young Spring shines, all prank'd with purple flowers; Thy Winter with its chilling clouds assails; Thine Autumn noisy Bacchus distributes".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:244
verses.text: Then he adds, naming expressly the Almighty God:—  "Deathless Immortal, capable of being To the immortals only uttered! Come, Greatest of gods, with strong Necessity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:245
verses.text: Dread, invincible, great, deathless One, Whom Ether crowns".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:246
verses.text: …  By the expression "Sire of our Mother" (μητροπάτωρ) he not only intimates creation out of nothing, but gives occasion to those who introduce emissions of imagining a consort of the Deity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:247
verses.text: And he paraphrases those prophetic Scripture—that in Isaiah, "I am He that fixes the thunder, and creates the wind; whose hands have founded the host of heaven;" and that in Moses, "Behold, behold that I am He, and there is no god beside me: I will kill, and I will make to live; I will smite, and I will heal: and there is none that shall deliver out of my hands".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:248
verses.text: "And He, from good, to mortals planteth ill, And cruel war, and tearful woes,"  according to Orpheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:249
verses.text: Such also are the words of the Parian Archilochus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:250
verses.text: "O Zeus, thine is the power of heaven, and thou Inflict'st on men things violent and wrong".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:251
verses.text: Again let the Thracian Orpheus sing to us:—  "His right hand all around to ocean's bound He stretches; and beneath His feet is earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:252
verses.text: These are plainly derived from the following: "The Lord will save the inhabited cities, and grasp the whole land in His hand like a nest;" "It is the Lord that made the earth by His power," as saith Jeremiah, "and set up the earth by His wisdom".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:253
verses.text: Further, in addition to these, Phocylides, who calls the angels demons, explains in the following words that some of them are good, and others bad (for we also have learned that some are apostate):—  "Demons there are—some here, some there—set over men; Some, on man's entrance into life, to ward off ill".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:254
verses.text: Rightly, then, also Philemon, the comic poet demolishes idolatry in these words:—  "Fortune is no divinity to us: There's no such god.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:255
verses.text: But what befalls by chance And of itself to each, is Fortune called".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:256
verses.text: And Sophocles the tragedian says:—  "Not even the gods have all things as they choose, Excepting Zeus; for he beginning is and end".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:257
verses.text: And Orpheus:—  "One Might, the great, the flaming heaven, was One Deity.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:258
verses.text: All things one Being were; in whom All these revolve fire, water, and the earth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:259
verses.text: And so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:260
verses.text: Pindar, the lyric poet, as if in Bacchic frenzy, plainly says:—  "What is God? The All".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:261
verses.text: And again:—  "God, who makes all mortals".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:262
verses.text: And when he says,—  "How little, being a man, dost thou expect Wisdom for man? 'Tis hard for mortal mind The counsels of the gods to scan; and thou Wast of a mortal mother born,"  he drew the thought from the following: "Who hath known the mind of the Lord, or who was His counsellor?" Hesiod, too, agrees with what is said above, in what he writes:—  "No prophet, sprung of men that dwell on earth, Can know the mind of aegis-bearing Zeus".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:263
verses.text: Similarly, then, Solon the Athenian, in the Elegies, following Hesiod, writes:—  "The immortal's mind to men is quite unknown".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:264
verses.text: Again Moses, having prophesied that the woman would bring forth in trouble and pain, on account of transgression, a poet not undistinguished writes:—  "Never by day From toil and woe shall they have rest, nor yet By night from groans.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:265
verses.text: Sad cares the gods to men Shall give".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:266
verses.text: Further, when Homer says,—  "The Sire himself the golden balance held,"  he intimates that God is just.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:267
verses.text: And Menander, the comic poet, in exhibiting God, says:—  "To each man, on his birth, there is assigned A tutelary Demon, as his life's good guide.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:268
verses.text: For that the Demon evil is, and harms A good life, is not to be thought".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:269
verses.text: Then he adds:—  "Ἅπαντα δ᾽ ἁγαθὸν εἱναι τὸν Θεόν,"  meaning either "that every one good is God," or, what is preferable, "that God in all things is good".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:270
verses.text: Again, aeschylus the tragedian, setting forth the power of God, does not shrink from calling Him the Highest, in these words:—  "Place God apart from mortals; and think not That He is, like thyself, corporeal.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:271
verses.text: Thou know'st Him not.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:272
verses.text: Now He appears as fire, Dread force; as water now; and now as gloom; And in the beasts is dimly shadowed forth, In wind, and cloud, in lightning, thunder, rain; And minister to Him the seas and rocks, Each fountain and the water's floods and streams.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:273
verses.text: The mountains tremble, and the earth, the vast Abyss of sea, and towering height of hills, When on them looks the Sovereign's awful eye: Almighty is the glory of the Most High God".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:274
verses.text: Does he not seem to you to paraphrase that text, "At the presence of the Lord the earth trembles?" In addition to these, the most prophetic Apollo is compelled—thus testifying to the glory of God—to say of Athene, when the Medes made war against Greece, that she besought and supplicated Zeus for Attica.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:275
verses.text: The oracle is as follows:—  "Pallas cannot Olympian Zeus propitiate, Although with many words and sage advice she prays; But he will give to the devouring fire many temples of the immortals, Who now stand shaking with terror, and bathed in sweat;"  and so forth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:276
verses.text: Thearidas, in his book On Nature, writes: "There was then one really true beginning first principle of all that exist"—one.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:277
verses.text: For that Being in the beginning is one and alone".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:278
verses.text: "Nor is there any other except the Great King,"  says Orpheus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:279
verses.text: In accordance with whom, the comic poet Diphilus says very sententiously, the  "Father of all, To Him alone incessant reverence pay, The inventor and the author of such blessings".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:280
verses.text: Rightly therefore Plato "accustoms the best natures to attain to that study which formerly we said was the highest, both to see the good and to accomplish that ascent.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:281
verses.text: And this, as appears, is not the throwing of the potsherds; but the turning round of the soul from a nocturnal day to that which is a true return to that which really is, which we shall assert to be the true philosophy".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:282
verses.text: Such as are partakers of this he judges to belong to the golden race, when he says: "Ye are all brethren; and those who are of the golden race are most capable of judging most accurately in every respect".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:283
verses.text: The Father, then, and Maker of all things is apprehended by all things, agreeably to all, by innate power and without teaching,—things inanimate, sympathizing with the animate creation; and of living beings some are already immoral, working in the light of day.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:284
verses.text: But of those that are still mortal, some are in fear, and carried still in their mother's womb; and others regulate themselves by their own independent reason.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:285
verses.text: And of men all are Greeks and Barbarians.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:286
verses.text: But no race anywhere of tillers of the soil, or nomads, and not even of dwellers in cities, can live, without being imbued with the faith of a superior being.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:287
verses.text: Wherefore every eastern nation, and every nation touching the western shore; or the north, and each one towards the south,—all have one and the same preconception respecting Him who hath appointed government; since the most universal of His operations equally pervade all.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:288
verses.text: Much more did the philosophers among the Greeks, devoted to investigation, starting from the Barbarian philosophy, attribute providence to the "Invisible, and sole, and most powerful, and most skilful and supreme cause of all things most beautiful;"—not knowing the inferences from these truths, unless instructed by us, and not even how God is to be known naturally; but only, as we have already often said, by a true periphrasis.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:289
verses.text: Rightly therefore the apostle says, "Is He the God of the Jews only, and not also of the Greeks?"—not only saying prophetically that of the Greeks believing Greeks would know God; but also intimating that in power the Lord is the God of all, and truly Universal King.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:290
verses.text: For they know neither what He is, nor how He is Lord, and Father, and Maker, nor the rest of the system of the truth, without being taught by it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:291
verses.text: Thus also the prophetic utterances have the same force as the apostolic word.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:292
verses.text: For Isaiah says, "If ye say, We trust in the Lord our God: now make an alliance with my Lord the king of the Assyrians".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:293
verses.text: And he adds: "And now, was it without the Lord that we came up to this land to make war against it?" And Jonah, himself a prophet, intimates the same thing in what he says: "And the shipmaster came to him, and  said to him, Why dost thou snore? Rise, call on thy God, that He may save us, and that we may not perish".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:294
verses.text: For the expression "thy God" he makes as if to one who knew Him by way of knowledge; and the expression, "that God may save us," revealed the consciousness in the minds of heathens who had applied their mind to the Ruler of all, but had not yet believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:295
verses.text: And again the same: "And he said to them, I am the servant of the Lord; and I fear the Lord, the God of heaven".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:296
verses.text: And again the same: "And he said, Let us by no means perish for the life of this man".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:297
verses.text: And Malachi the prophet plainly exhibits God saying, "I will not accept sacrifice at your hands.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:298
verses.text: For from the rising of the sun to its going down, My name is glorified among the Gentiles; and in every place sacrifice is offered to Me".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:299
verses.text: And again: "Because I am a great King, saith the Lord omnipotent; and My name is manifest among the nations".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:300
verses.text: What name? The Son declaring the Father among the Greeks who have believed.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:301
verses.text: Plato in what follows gives an exhibition of free-will: "Virtue owns not a master; and in proportion as each one honours or dishonours it, in that proportion he will be a partaker of it.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:302
verses.text: The blame lies in the exercise of free choice".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:303
verses.text: But God is blameless.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:304
verses.text: For He is never the author of evil.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:305
verses.text: "O warlike Trojans," says the lyric poet,—  "High ruling Zeus, who beholds all things, Is not the cause of great woes to mortals; But it is in the power of all men to find Justice, holy, pure, Companion of order, And of wise Themis The sons of the blessed are ye In finding her as your associate".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:306
verses.text: And Pindar expressly introduces also Zeus Soter, the consort of Themis, proclaiming him King, Saviour, Just, in the following lines:—  "First, prudent Themis, of celestial birth, On golden steeds, by Ocean's rock, The Fates brought to the stair sublime, The shining entrance of Olympus, Of Saviour Zeus for aye to be the spouse, And she, the Hours, gold-diademed, fair-fruited, good, brought forth".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:307
verses.text: He, then, who is not obedient to the truth, and is puffed up with human teaching, is wretched and miserable, according to Euripides:—  "Who these things seeing, yet apprehends not God, But mouthing lofty themes, casts far Perverse deceits; stubborn in which, the tongue Its shafts discharges, about things unseen, Devoid of sense".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:308
verses.text: Let him who wishes, then, approaching to the true instruction, learn from Parmenides the Eleatic, who promises:—  "Ethereal nature, then, and all the signs In Ether thou shall know, and the effects, All viewless, of the sacred Sun's clear torch And whence produced.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:309
verses.text: The round-eyed Moon's Revolving influences and nature thou Shall learn; and the ensphering heaven shall know; Whence sprung; and how Necessity took it And chained so as to keep the starry bounds".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:310
verses.text: And Metrodorus, though an Epicurean, spoke thus, divinely inspired: "Remember, O Menestratus, that, being a mortal endowed with a circumscribed life, thou hast in thy soul ascended, till thou hast seen endless time, and the infinity of things; and what is to be, and what has been;" when with the blessed choir, according to Plato, we shall gaze on the blessed sight and vision; we following with Zeus, and others with other deities, if we may be permitted so to say, to receive initiation into the most blessed mystery: which we shall celebrate, ourselves being perfect and untroubled by the ills which awaited us at the end of our time; and introduced to the knowledge of perfect and tranquil visions, and contemplating them in pure sunlight; we ourselves pure, and now no longer distinguished by that, which, when carrying it about, we call the body, being bound to it like an oyster to its shell.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:311
verses.text: The Pythagoreans call heaven the Antichthon the opposite Earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:312
verses.text: And in this land, it is said by Jeremiah, "I will place thee among the children, and give thee the chosen land as inheritance of God Omnipotent;" and they who inherit it shall reign over the earth.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:313
verses.text: Myriads on myriads of examples rush on my mind which might adduce.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:314
verses.text: But for the sake of symmetry the discourse must now stop, in order that we may not exemplify the saying of Agatho the tragedian:—  "Treating our by-work as work, And doing our work as by-work".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:315
verses.text: It having been, then, as I think, clearly shown in what way it is to be understood that the Greeks were called thieves by the Lord, I willingly leave the dogmas of the philosophers.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:316
verses.text: For were we to go over their sayings, we should gather together directly such a quantity of notes, in showing that the whole of the Hellenic wisdom was derived from the Barbarian philosophy.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:317
verses.text: But this speculation, we shall, nevertheless, again touch on, as necessity requires, when we collect the opinions current among the Greeks respecting first principles.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:318
verses.text: But from what has been said, it tacitly devolves on us to consider in what way the Hellenic books  are to be perused by the man who is able to pass through the billows in them.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:319
verses.text: Therefore  "Happy is he who possesses the wealth of the divine mind,"  as appears according to Empedocles,  "But wretched he, who cares for dark opinion about the Gods".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:320
verses.text: He divinely showed knowledge and ignorance to be the boundaries of happiness and misery.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:321
verses.text: "For it behoves philosophers to be acquainted with very many things," according to Heraclitus; and truly must  "He, who seeks to be good, err in many things".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:322
verses.text: It is then now clear to us, from what has been said, that the beneficence of God is eternal, and that, from an unbeginning principle, equal natural righteousness reached all, according to the worth of each several race,—never having had a beginning.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:323
verses.text: For God did not make a beginning of being Lord and Good, being always what He is.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:324
verses.text: Nor will He ever cease to do good, although He bring all things to an end.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:325
verses.text: And each one of us is a partaker of His beneficence, as far as He wills.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:326
verses.text: For the difference of the elect is made by the intervention of a choice worthy of the soul, and by exercise.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:327
verses.text: Thus, then, let our fifth Miscellany of gnostic notes in accordance with the true philosophy be brought to a close.

verses.text: Elucidations.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:333
verses.text: ), I must here translate a few words from Philo Judaeus.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:334
verses.text: He says, "Before Abram was called, such was his name; but afterward he was named Abraam, by the simple duplication of one letter, which nevertheless enfolds a great significance.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:335
verses.text: For Abram is expounded to mean sublime father, but Abraam means elect father of sound".

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:336
verses.text: Philo goes on to give his personal fancies in explication of this whim.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:337
verses.text: But, with Clement, Philo was an expert, to whom all knowledge was to be credited in his specialty.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:338
verses.text: This passage, however, confirms the opinion of those who pronounce Clement destitute of Hebrew, even in its elements.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:339
verses.text: No need to say that Abram means something like what Philo gives us, but Abraham is expounded in the Bible itself (Genesis :).

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:340
verses.text: The text of the LXX, seems to have been dubious to our author's mind, and hence he fails back on Philo.

verses.name: Clement of Alexandria: The Stromata Book V 15:341
verses.text: But this of itself appears decisive as to Clement's Hebrew scholarship.
